added_lines: Gnocchi dispatcher ------------------ The Telemetry module supports sending the metering data to Gnocchi backend through the gnocchi dispatcher. To set this option as the target, the ``dispatcher`` has to be changed to ``gnocchi`` in the :file:`ceilometer.conf` configuration file. For the list of options that you need to set, see the `dispatcher_gnocchi section <http://docs.openstack.org/liberty/config-reference/content/ch_configuring-openstack-telemetry.html>`__ in the OpenStack Configuration Reference.

commit_message:
Add the validation for /NetworkDriver.Join

This patch adds the JSON Schema and the validation with it for
/NetworkDriver.Join endpoint. This patch inclues the unit tests for that
as well.

Change-Id: I67cf652f98273634ab614a6173587a6e88609fe0
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/10/223510/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Binds a Neutron Port to a physical interface attached to a container. This function takes the following JSON data, creates a veth pair, put one end inside of the container and binds another end to the Neutron Port specified in the request.:: { "NetworkID": string, "EndpointID": string, "SandboxKey": string, "Options": { ... } } If the binding is succeeded, the following JSON response is returned.:: { "InterfaceName": { SrcName: string, DstPrefix: string }, "Gateway": string, "GatewayIPv6": string, "StaticRoutes": [{ "Destination": string, "RouteType": int, "NextHop": string, }, ...] } See the following link for more details about the spec: https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/blob/master/docs/remote.md#join # noqa """ json_data = flask.request.get_json(force=True) app.logger.debug("Received JSON data {0} for /NetworkDriver.Join" .format(json_data)) jsonschema.validate(json_data, schemata.JOIN_SCHEMA)

commit_message:
Ensure remote mysql root connection enforces password

Currently only a single connection is allowed for root
and this is from localhost  in a passwordless way.

This commit aims to allow remote connection and enforce the password for
mysql root user.

Change-Id: I5c72edd75483030948ce7e06545e85fbd7a5c854
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/14/209014/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $mysql_root_password = hiera('mysql::server::root_password') $mysql_bind_host = hiera('mysql_bind_host') $mysql_bind_vip = hiera('mysql_vip') mysql_user { "root@${mysql_bind_host}" : ensure => present, password_hash => mysql_password($mysql_root_password), } mysql_user { "root@${mysql_vip}" : ensure => present, password_hash => mysql_password($mysql_root_password), }

commit_message:
Ensure root user has a password set

Currently root users are set without password for various origin :

  * localhost
  * ::1
  * 127.0.0.1
  * <HOSTNAME>

This patchset enforces that default origins account are removed
(::1, 127.0.0.1 and <HOSTNAME>).

It also ensures that root@localhost has the password enforced.

Co-Authored-By: Jiri Stransky <jistr@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id28a4d45215bb1090b1e15e262c5b59817119336
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/39/208639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mysql::server::remove_default_accounts: true

subject: Fix devstack option to plugin zaqar
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-16 06:34:23.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/development-environment.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/30c37dcdad2b184c36987070a0aad4a9efe6c79f', 'message': 'Fix devstack option to plugin zaqar

As per zaqar development-environment.rst,
To integrate zaqar in an openstack environment,
we need to enable zagar service by adding the below line to the devstack local.conf
	enable_service zaqar-server
However, now zaqar add as a plugin (not as a devstack service) to
the devstack environment by adding below line to the devstack local.conf
	enable_plugin zaqar https://github.com/openstack/zaqar
This patch is fixed the issue.
Closes-Bug: #1496233

Change-Id: I677257c2f3ae4caa3f39fde2fabee9ee5c113a5c
'}]
commit_message:
Fix devstack option to plugin zaqar

As per zaqar development-environment.rst,
To integrate zaqar in an openstack environment,
we need to enable zagar service by adding the below line to the devstack local.conf
	enable_service zaqar-server
However, now zaqar add as a plugin (not as a devstack service) to
the devstack environment by adding below line to the devstack local.conf
	enable_plugin zaqar https://github.com/openstack/zaqar
This patch is fixed the issue.
Closes-Bug: #1496233

Change-Id: I677257c2f3ae4caa3f39fde2fabee9ee5c113a5c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/40/223940/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: enable_plugin zaqar https://github.com/openstack/zaqar

commit_message:
stack-update -x tolerate no template

Replacement for the approach outlined in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154692/

This works with the following heat changes to enable
full PATCH update functionality, including omitting
the template or environment:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/205754/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154619/

Closes-Bug: #1224828
Change-Id: I2a82936743badb69f0de5a6ca64f95ae63a35358

commit_message:
Raise python-3 compatible exceptions

This commit updates the code to raise python-3 comaptible exceptions.
This would be useful for making congress python34 compatible.

Partially implements blueprint: support-python3

commit_message:
Fix criteria for selecting default bridge provider

Compare version with correct version (2014.2.2-6.1) where linux bridge driver
for bridges was introduced.
Select port action by the first bridge in list if provider is 'ovs'.

Change-Id: Ic32e49c3749ff290a0ffd52ee16248ae9165aaff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/07/223607/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if version < LooseVersion('2014.2.2-6.1'): if bridges[0] == bridge:
deleted_lines: if version < LooseVersion('2014.2-6.1'): if bridge in bridges:

commit_message:
Docker containers packages shouldn't be updated from repos

For perventing upgrading packages in docker containers
we disable repos before running DockerUpgrader and restore them
on DockerUpgreder success or rollback.

Change-Id: Ib2481e1dd59f28b874b415ba57b48a61a259e20d
Related-Bug: #1494640

commit_message:
Fix nova configuration options description

iscsi_use_multipath = False(BoolOpt) Use multipath connection of the
iSCSI volume
above description is incorrect and very misleading
actually, this option is applicable for both FC/iSCSI volumes

Change-Id: I9bbae44c465f14ed6cabb084d17cecde77843c88
Closes-bug: #1495876
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/23/223623/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: (BoolOpt) Use multipath connection of the iSCSI or FC volume
deleted_lines: (BoolOpt) Use multipath connection of the iSCSI volume

added_lines: from xml.etree import ElementTree_default_exclude_services = ('p_mysql', 'p_haproxy', 'p_dns', 'p_ntp')def get_crm_services(status_out, exclude=_default_exclude_services): data = ElementTree.fromstring(status_out) for resource in data.find('resources'): name = resource.get('id') if any(service in name for service in exclude): continue yield name status_out = ssh.call_output(['crm_mon', '--as-xml'], node=node) for service in get_crm_services(status_out):

Add row delete action in profiles table
And add "Delete Profiles" action to table.

Partially implements blueprint add-profile-panel

added_lines: from django.utils.translation import ungettext_lazyfrom senlin_dashboard import api class DeleteProfile(tables.DeleteAction): @staticmethod def action_present(count): return ungettext_lazy( u"Delete Profile", u"Delete Profiles", count ) @staticmethod def action_past(count): return ungettext_lazy( u"Deleted Profile", u"Deleted Profiles", count ) def delete(self, request, obj_id): api.senlin.profile_delete(request, obj_id) row_actions = (DeleteProfile,)

commit_message:
Instance Users for Cloud Interaction

Instances have need to some times interact with the cloud that it is
running under. This can include getting keys from Barbican, putting
messages in a Zaqar queue, getting a file from Swift, etc. All of
these services require a fresh Keystone token.

APIImpact

Change-Id: Iae2d45d87fc11f6918d93ff032d4a5b5a19f88c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/17/186617/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Instance Users for Cloud Interaction ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/example Instances have need to some times interact with the cloud that it is running under. This can include getting keys from Barbican, putting messages in a Zaqar queue, getting a file from Swift, etc. All of these services require a fresh Keystone token. Problem description =================== Instances need a way of getting fresh Keystone Tokens so that they can talk to other OpenStack services. Use Cases ---------- Developers will use this when writing heat templates to allow Instances to securely fetch secrets they need to properly operate from Barbican without storing secrets in the Nova and/or Heat database. Various OpenStack services that launch Instances with Guest Agents can use This to allow communication between controller nodes and the guest agent via Zaqar. Project Priority ----------------- Unknown Proposed change =============== The following changes will enable a smooth workflow to be established between Nova, the Instance, and other OpenStack services. 1. The nova database will be extended to support extra metadata of a Keystone password per Instance. 2. Config options will be added to nova.conf to specify a Keystone Domain to use and which Keystone endpoint url to hand to the Instance. 3. The metadata server api will be extended to provide a place to fetch a fresh keystone token. This api will create a new Keystone user in the specified Keystone Domain with a username of the Instance's UUID and a random password, if a password is not already stored in the db. This allows Instances that don't need an instance user to not get one. After creation, the Keystone User UUID will be added to the Instances user visible metadata as well. The Password is never returned to the user, only kept internally. It is used to Hand out unscoped Keystone tokens to the user of the api. Alternatives ------------ A more specific, Barbican only solution is is specified here: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/vm-integration Data model impact ----------------- This change adds one column to the database. If its value is null, it will be populated on first token request. This provides a simple upgrade path. REST API impact --------------- This change adds one method to the metadata server at: http://169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/keystone.json It supports only the GET method. It is expected to return a json document that looks something like: { "instance_uuid": "c7b6a27e-7244-4c85-b634-7bac93f11e6b", "catalog": { "extras": {}, "methods": [ "password" ], "version": "v3", "audit_ids": [ "xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx" ], "issued_at": "2015-05-28T00:37:54.270572Z", "auth_token": "xxxxxxx", "expires_at": "2015-05-29T00:37:54.270552Z", "user": { "domain": { "id": "53d6bfad58074b4cbff99e8e12108081", "name": "nova" }, "id": "4c02456a531c44b3b9f099d020a6c2ba", "name": "c7b6a27e-7244-4c85-b634-7bac93f11e6b" } }, "auth_url": "http://10.254.254.1:35357/v3", "region": "RegionOne" } It is basically just the output of the keystoneclient v3 Client.service_catalog.catalog, along with a keystone endpoint url, and the Region the Instance is in. Security impact --------------- This change allows Instances to discover the Keystone endpoint associated with their Instance, what Region, and get an Unscoped Keystone token. No initial privileges will be granted to the User so in theory, it won't be able to do anything unless some other user associates a trust with the Instance User or ACL's on Barbican resources. This change is a net security enhancement since users today must create a Keystone User manually, handling a password, pass it through Heat and/or Nova, storing it in those databases unencrypted and storing the password permanently in the Instance. With this change, all of those things are avoided. No one can login to the Instance and copy its credentials since it is never given direct access to them. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- This change will probably will impact the OpenStack unified client to enable it to easily fetch keys itself. Performance Impact ------------------ The new code will be called only when an Instance needs a fresh Keystone Token. This should be infrequent. Other deployer impact --------------------- To enable the feature, a new Keystone Domain will need to be created by the deployer and passed in the config to Nova. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: kevpn Work Items ---------- * Add new Config Options * Add new DB Column * Implement Metadata Server API addition Dependencies ============ None currently. More specs will be added in Barbican, Keystone, Keystone Client, Heat, Barbican, Barbican Client and OpenStackClient to make this feature truly useful to the community. Testing ======= I think unit testing the new endpoint is easily done. Documentation Impact ==================== This change will impact the documentation related to the new Metadata Server API, but it is a minimal change. References ========== * A lot of discussion with various folks at the Vancouver Summit. History ======= Optional section for liberty intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

also IP address linking, for example the symbolic link:

commit_message:
Allow tftpd usage of '--secure' by using symlinks

Create symbolic links in the tftp_root with relative paths. This is to
allow the tftpd server to be run in '--secure' mode.  '--secure' mode
has the daemon doing a chroot upon startup into the specified tftp_root
directory.

Absolute path symbolic links break the use of the '--secure' option.
Using a 'map-file' does not fix the breakage.

For example, previously Ironic might create the file:
     /var/lib/tftpboot/pxelinux.cfg/01-b8-ae-ed-71-18-52 which is a
symbolic link to:
  -> /var/lib/tftpboot/cf15449c-7d09-4b6c-b2db-7e07795ebc98/config

It will now use relative symbolic links so that:
     /var/lib/tftpboot/pxelinux.cfg/01-b8-ae-ed-71-18-52 is a symbolic
link to:
  -> ../cf15449c-7d09-4b6c-b2db-7e07795ebc98/config

This change will affect MAC address linking, for example the symbolic
link:
  /var/lib/tftpboot/pxelinux.cfg/01-b8-ae-ed-71-18-52
also IP address linking, for example the symbolic link:
  /var/lib/tftpboot/10.0.0.1.conf

Change-Id: I0f65030fe044aa19294f5389dbdb829ede61032a
Closes-Bug: #1494991

commit_message:
Properly patch _init_overrides_dir in MongoDB

Since most of us don't have MongoDB installed on our
desktop/development environment, tox tests will fail because some
config paths for Mongo aren't available.

The change proposed here is merely to mock the _init_overrides_dir
properly in changes that would otherwise stub their toes on this.

It is my understanding that this issue was introduced in Change-Id:
Iaca9cc9e3ce1e6521839062fc9458c1b987f9464 which sought to address bug
1485158.

The reason this problem occurs on my machine (and likely on other
developers workstation) is that I don't have MongoDB installed. The
reason this doesn't impact the gate is that those machines have
MongoDB installed (for ceiliometer).

Change-Id: I0f3d24b95a7d2ef1e23a0f1fd8f60bc496261f70
Closes-Bug: #1495573

commit_message:
Prevent full sync in dhcp_agent when possible

If an exception occurs in sync_state method, we try for a full sync
even in the case where we have fewer networks to resync for.

This turns out to be pretty costly in scaled environments.

This patch addresses the above behavior by resyncing only for the
eariler set of failed networks.

Closes-Bug: #1495592

Change-Id: I069e992b3b7814370d409236b6a3c81a25829cc1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/46/222546/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix cells use of legacy bdms during local instance delete operations

The instance delete code paths were changed to use new-world bdm objects
in commit f5071bd1ac00ed68102d37c8025d36df6777cd9e.

However, cells code still use the legacy format for local delete
operations which is clearly wrong. Code that gets called in the parent
class in nova/compute/api.py uses dot-notation and calls bdm.destroy()
as well.

This change replace the old bdm lookup call to use objects instead.

Change-Id: Id68330eb238a304eaceefa7c0ec2fa0d2b60d28a
Closes-Bug: #1486541

commit_message:
Truncate Nagios detail output to <2048 characters

If the nagios_wrapper polls a check which produces more than 2048
characters of value_meta 'detail' output, the API will throw an
error.  This change truncates the 'detail' output to be under that
2048-character limit.

Change-Id: Id10a380afbe78c58d1a207966d4d055e3d3ad0fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/46/222746/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: value_meta={'detail': detail[0:2047]})

commit_message:
Remove watchdog from the agent

The watchdog is causing problems by restarting the agent
even if it does not need to. Also we are not gaining
anything by running it. In result we are removing
watchdog completely from the agent.

Change-Id: I45b80e28d81749c98dff7273d7756e10db23da70
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/09/215809/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: import unittest import subprocess import os import sys from random import random, randrange import urllib as url import time sys.path.append(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '../monasca_agent')) from monasca_agent.collector.daemon import CollectorDaemon from monasca_agent.common.util import Watchdog class TestWatchdog(unittest.TestCase): """Test watchdog in various conditions """ JITTER_FACTOR = 2 def test_watchdog(self): """Verify that watchdog kills ourselves even when spinning Verify that watchdog kills ourselves when hanging """ start = time.time() try: subprocess.check_call( ["python", "tests/test_watchdog.py", "busy"], stderr=subprocess.STDOUT) raise Exception("Should have died with an error") except subprocess.CalledProcessError: duration = int(time.time() - start) self.assertTrue(duration < self.JITTER_FACTOR * 5) # Start pseudo web server subprocess.Popen(["nc", "-l", "31834"]) start = time.time() try: subprocess.check_call(["python", "tests/test_watchdog.py", "net"]) raise Exception("Should have died with an error") except subprocess.CalledProcessError: duration = int(time.time() - start) self.assertTrue(duration < self.JITTER_FACTOR * 5) # Normal loop, should run 5 times start = time.time() try: subprocess.check_call(["python", "tests/test_watchdog.py", "normal"]) duration = int(time.time() - start) self.assertTrue(duration < self.JITTER_FACTOR * 5) except subprocess.CalledProcessError: self.fail("Watchdog killed normal process after %s seconds" % int(time.time() - start)) # Fast tornado, not killed start = time.time() p = subprocess.Popen(["python", "tests/test_watchdog.py", "fast"]) p.wait() duration = int(time.time() - start) # should die as soon as flush_trs has been called self.assertTrue(duration, self.JITTER_FACTOR * 10) # Slow tornado, killed by the Watchdog start = time.time() p = subprocess.Popen(["python", "tests/test_watchdog.py", "slow"]) p.wait() duration = int(time.time() - start) self.assertTrue(duration < self.JITTER_FACTOR * 4) # Too much memory used, killed by Watchdog start = time.time() p = subprocess.Popen(["python", "tests/test_watchdog.py", "memory"]) p.wait() duration = int(time.time() - start) # process should be killed well before the restart interval of 30. assert duration < 20 class MockTxManager(object): @staticmethod def flush(): "Pretend to flush for a long time" time.sleep(5) sys.exit(0) class MemoryHogTxManager(object): @staticmethod def flush(): rand_data = [] while True: rand_data.append('%030x' % randrange(256 ** 15)) class PseudoAgent(object): """Same logic as the agent, simplified""" @staticmethod def busy_run(): w = Watchdog(5) w.reset() x = 0 while True: x = random() return x @staticmethod def hanging_net(): w = Watchdog(5) w.reset() x = url.urlopen("http://localhost:31834") print("ERROR Net call returned", x) return True @staticmethod def normal_run(): w = Watchdog(2) w.reset() for i in range(5): time.sleep(1) w.reset() @staticmethod def slow_tornado(): a = CollectorDaemon(12345, {}) a._watchdog = Watchdog(4) a._tr_manager = MockTxManager() a.run() @staticmethod def fast_tornado(): a = CollectorDaemon(12345, {}) a._watchdog = Watchdog(6) a._tr_manager = MockTxManager() a.run() @staticmethod def use_lots_of_memory(): # Skip this step on travis if os.environ.get('TRAVIS', False): return a = CollectorDaemon(12345, {}) a._watchdog = Watchdog(30, 50) a._tr_manager = MemoryHogTxManager() a.run() if __name__ == "__main__": if sys.argv[1] == "busy": a = PseudoAgent() a.busy_run() elif sys.argv[1] == "net": a = PseudoAgent() a.hanging_net() elif sys.argv[1] == "normal": a = PseudoAgent() a.normal_run() elif sys.argv[1] == "slow": a = PseudoAgent() a.slow_tornado() elif sys.argv[1] == "fast": a = PseudoAgent() a.fast_tornado() elif sys.argv[1] == "test": t = TestWatchdog() t.runTest() elif sys.argv[1] == "memory": a = PseudoAgent() a.use_lots_of_memory()

commit_message:
Add IronicFilter for ironic act-upon capabilities

This specs introduces to add a new filter to nova
scheduler which would be intelligent by itself
to differentiate between scheduling and driver capabilities.
For the driver capabilities, ironic need to take actions
based on the capability value given in nova-flavor.

Change-Id: Iab6f8fe63a1af75519e73ae307a5fa95366159ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/81/182581/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================================= Introduce IronicFilter for ironic drivers driver(act-upon) capabilities ======================================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ironicfilter-for-act-upon-capabilities Today Nova has number of operators supported for capabilities using which schedular selects the node for provisioning. Baremetal capabilities can be of two types: - Scheduling capabilities: which is just required for selecting the node. - driver capabilities: which require the ironic drivers to take some action on hardware. The nova operators in `nova/scheduler/filters/extra_specs_ops.py` are not required for driver capabilities. Mostly, ironic drivers require only the exact match for the driver capabilities. Nova need to be intelligent enough to differentiate between scheduling capabilities and driver capabilities. The `ComputeCapabilities` Filter in incapable of distinguishing between scheduling and driver capabilities. The new filter `IronicFilter` can be executed after the `ComputeCapabilities` Filter on the selected nodes. Problem description =================== Today Nova has number of operators supported for capabilities using which schedular selects the node for provisioning. Baremetal capabilities can be of two types: - Scheduling capabilities: which is just required for selecting the node. - driver capabilities: which require the ironic drivers to take some action on hardware. The nova operators in `nova/scheduler/filters/extra_specs_ops.py` are not required for driver capabilities. Mostly, ironic drivers require only the exact match for the driver capabilities. Nova need to be intelligent enough to differentiate between scheduling capabilities and driver capabilities. The `ComputeCapabilities` Filter in incapable of distinguishing between scheduling and driver capabilities as it selects node on the operators supported in `nova/scheduler/filters/extra_specs_ops.py`. The operators like `<in> , !=,` etc do not make sense for most of the driver capabilities. Example: ironic node has the capabilities defined as {'capabilities': 'boot_mode:uefi'} The flavor can have it in any form as below for node to be selected: - {'capabilities:boot_mode' : 'uefi'} - {'capabilities:boot_mode' : '<in> ue'} - {'capabilities:boot_mode' : '<!=> bios'} Just few examples above. There can be many more examples if we use all the operators supported by `nova/scheduler/filters/extra_specs_ops.py`. If node is selected for 2nd or 3rd case above, then the ironic driver doesn't know what action to take. Once nova schedular and ironic virt driver starts supporting json list as possible value for a capability, the above situations may become worse and it may not be possible for ironic drivers to handle all such negative cases of flavor creation for driver capabilities. Given above reasons, it is best to introduce a new filter `IronicFilter` which acts upon nodes selected by `ComputeCapabilities` filter and do a exact match of the driver capability value and handle only few operators which may apply to driver capabilities. Use Cases ---------- The new filter helps the Ironic to filter out the nodes if flavor is not created properly for the driver capabilities. Project Priority ----------------- This is required as Ironic already supports few of the driver capabilities in Kilo like `boot_mode`, `secure_boot`, `boot_option`. As of now ironic/nova doesn't handle any of the malformed flavor for above capabilities and the code assumes that the flavor is created properly for above. Proposed change =============== - Introduce a new filter `IronicFilter` which acts upon after the `ComputeCapabilities` filter. - define the supported operators for IronicFilter. - Get the possible driver capabilities and their possible values by using ironic API services like `get_driver_capabilities`. (https://github.com/openstack/ironic-specs/blob/master/specs/backlog/exposing-hardware-capabilities.rst) (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/131272/) - Check the defined flavor capabilities against all the driver capabilities and their values. If the capability key in flavor matches as a driver capability, `IronicFilter` do an appropriate operator check and gives the qualifying nodes for provisioning. - If node has been selected for provisioning, ironic virt driver copies only the driver capabilities to ironic node's `node.instance_info`. Alternatives ------------ - Introduce a new filter `IronicFilter` which acts upon after the `ComputeCapabilities` filter. - define the supported operators for IronicFilter. - Get the possible driver capabilities and their possible values from `ironic.conf` or `nova.conf`. - Check the defined flavor capabilities against all the driver capabilities and their values. If the capability key in flavor matches as a driver capability, `IronicFilter` do an appropriate operator check and gives the qualifying nodes for provisioning. - If node has been selected for provisioning, ironic virt driver copies only the driver capabilities to ironic node's `node.instance_info`. The above alternative can also be done. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- The node is selected only if the flavor is correctly created for driver capabilities which means the deploy is not failed due to incorrect node selection from nova. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: agarwalnisha1980 Work Items ---------- - Introduce a new filter `IronicFilter` which acts upon after the `ComputeCapabilities` filter. - define the supported operators for IronicFilter. - Get the possible driver capabilities and their possible values by using ironic API services like `get_driver_capabilities`. (https://github.com/openstack/ironic-specs/blob/master/specs/backlog/exposing-hardware-capabilities.rst) (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/131272/) - Check the defined flavor capabilities against all the driver capabilities and their values. If the capability key in flavor matches as a driver capability, `IronicFilter` do an appropriate operator check and gives the qualifying nodes for provisioning. - If node has been selected for provisioning, ironic virt driver copies only the driver capabilities to ironic node's `node.instance_info`. Dependencies ============ https://github.com/openstack/ironic-specs/blob/master/specs/backlog/exposing-hardware-capabilities.rst Testing ======= Different scenarios need to be covered: - IronicFilter used only for ironic services/nodes. - IronicFilter selects node via only the supported operators for IronicFilter. - IronicFilter is able to distinguish between driver capabilities and scheduling capabilities. - The ironic node's `node.instance_info` is populated only with driver capabilities given in flavor. Documentation Impact ==================== It would be required to document the supported operators for new filter, `IronicFilter`. References ========== https://review.openstack.org/#/c/131272/ History ======= Optional section for liberty intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

commit_message:
Add config-filter spec

Change-Id: I0bf28aafa62ae90a85baf0a795a982fe792b31ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/75/173375/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Config-based scheduler filter ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/config-filter Right now, failed instance boots due to unexpected scheduling decisions are hard to debug. In many cases, this is due to improper configuration of the scheduler, compute nodes, or a mismatch between the configuration and expectations of the operator. In many cases, having the scheduler try to sanity-check a boot request against the deployment configuration would be helpful. Problem description =================== Most scheduler filters require certain configurations to function, but do not fail gracefully in their absence. Use Cases ---------- * Operators want to enable an advanced feature like PCI passthrough or NUMA, and need to validate that instances with these advanced features can be booted. * Users want to boot instances with advanced features, but have no visibility into the deployment config, and want to have more concrete explanations if and when things fail. Project Priority ----------------- These are undefined, as of yet. Proposed change =============== I propose a "config filter" or "newbie filter" that can be enabled by default, and positioned to run first in the sequence. This filter will examine a boot request, and compare it against the system configuration (and potentially other details) to cause a fast fail of the request with a helpful fault message. Examples of this would be: * An attempt to boot an instance with a prescribed NUMA topology on a hypervisor known not to support NUMA. * An attempt to boot an instance with a prescribed NUMA topology, when the NUMA scheduler filter is not enabled * An attempt to boot an instance with a PCI request, when the PCI scheduler filter is not enabled By running first and quickly, this filter can fail the boot request early and set the instance state and fault message to something helpful, such as: "You requested a PCI device, but this deployment is not configured for PCI passthrough." Alternatives ------------ We could do nothing. This is just an attempt to improve the UX for the operators and users around scheduling when the request doesn't make sense. Improving docs may help people not hit these issues in the first place, but no amount of improved documentation will prevent it all. Data model impact ----------------- We should not need any changes. We already have an instance state of ERROR, combined with the instance_fault property on an instance which is our mechanism to communicate the details of "why" the request failed to the user. REST API impact --------------- There is no mechanical change required to the API. In practice, a doomed boot request will still fail, but quicker and with more helpful information. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- Improved discoverability of failures and their reasoning. Performance Impact ------------------ This will potentially reduce load on the scheduler. By running early and being mostly static comparisons, we will eliminate ill-fated requests from running through the rest of the filter stack, and in some cases, from hitting the compute node before we discover that they are unsatisfyable. Other deployer impact --------------------- In reality, public cloud deployers may decide not to leave this filter enabled in production. When standing up a new deployment, it will help increase the time to verification of the environment, but may not be something that would be left in place. However, most private clouds will likely want it to be there for the increased information it provides to the users. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: (I think I will try to find someone to work on this) Other contributors: danms Work Items ---------- * Enumerate conditions that we can validate * Write a new scheduler filter to check those conditions * Write functional tests to validate them * Write at least one tempest test to validate the filter behavior externally Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Each situation should be independently verifiable using unit and functional tests in the Nova tree. At least one scenario should be added to and verified by tempest to ensure that the high-level functionality actually works. Documentation Impact ==================== Minimal, if any. This should most just increase the information to the users in a discoverable way. We may want to update operator documentation to explain the point of the filter, as well as point out that it may be desirable to remove it before entering production. References ==========

commit_message:
Refactor allocate_for_instance

Split allocate_for_instance into logical function groups, make better
use of the neutron API by coalescing multiple calls into one where
supported and support asynchronous operations where appropriate.

blueprint nova-neutron-refactor

Change-Id: I32aee20c0bab86242a74ee01f81921a77683565b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/29/141129/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================== Refactor allocate_for_instance =============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-neutron-refactor `allocate_for_instance` in the Network API adapter for neutron has grown prohibitively complex and is a gallery of sins. On the critical path, the successful refactoring of this method represents a significant step forward towards reducing technical debt. Problem description =================== The longest method in terms of lines of code in the Network API adapter, `allocate_for_instance` is on the critical path for building all Openstack instances. The API method itself is a single point for requesting network resources for an instance. The operations that are performed on behalf of this API call vary depending on the parameters. * If no network is requested, neutron is queried for networks that the tenant has access to. An exception is thrown if there is more that one. Port will be created and assigned to the instance if successful. * If one or more networks are requested by network ID, neutron is queried to verify that the tenant can access these networks. Ports will be created and assigned to the instance. * If one or more ports are requested, neutron is queried for port information, verifying access to the related network and obtaining the network ID. * Variants combining the second and third scenarios can also occur. All of these variants are handled by this single method with the exception of a few dedicated helper methods that simply reduce the line count of `allocate_for_instance` itself. The serial nature in which these different scenarios prevent invoking unrelated operations asynchronously and concurrently and batching multiple queries in a single call. Use Cases ---------- `allocate_for_instance` is one of the most critical integration points between nova and neutron and needs to be as maintainable, testable and extensible as possible. Project Priority ----------------- This refactoring addresses an issue of significant techncial dept and facilitates Nova to Neutron migration. Proposed change =============== This refactor splits the principle use cases supported by `allocate_for_instance` into separate distinct code paths, refactoring common code into helper methods. Operations such as listing ports and networks will be done as single neutron calls as well operations for the creation, updating and deletion of ports. .. note:: Updating multiple ports at a time may not be supported by the neutron API at this time. If that remains to be the case at the relevant time, the lack of functionality will be hidden in the related neutron client wrapper. Alternatives ------------ There is no appropriate alternative. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Brent Eagles (beagles@redhat.com) is leading this refactoring. One or more sponsors from the core teams should have direct involvement in an, at minimum, advisory capacity. Particularly: * Dan Smith - Nova: objects, data model and migration. * Matt Riedemann * Gary Kotton * Matthew Gillard Primary assignee: * Brent Eagles beagles@redhat.com Work Items ---------- 1. Reimplement the no requested network case in terms of the neutronclient wrapper. Allocations with requested networks will continue to use existing implementation. 2. Reimplement requested network case with network ids. Allocations with requested networks involving ports will continue using the existing implementation. 3. Reimplement requested network case with ports and combinations of request types. 4. Support asynchronous querying of ports, networks and security groups. Dependencies ============ * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/141108/ Wrap neutron client calls. Testing ======= As this is part of the Nova-Neutron API refactoring, a CI job will in the experimental work queue will run the new Tempest tests Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ==========

commit_message:
Fix no tenant name in admin image panel when UpdateRow

Admin Images table when the image have UpdateRow action,
it will give the message:
The attribute tenant_name doesn't exist on <Image {u'status': u'saving',
u'name': u'cirros', u'deleted': False, u'container_format': u'bare',
u'created_at': u'2015-06-23T01:59:28.000000',...}>,
and can not display the tenant name.
This patch fix it.

Change-Id: I00e8e07bf3002b271328bde15480afa33afa01bc
Closes-Bug: #1495862
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/86/223486/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from horizon import exceptions if image: try: tenants, more = api.keystone.tenant_list(request) except Exception: tenants = [] msg = _('Unable to retrieve project list.') exceptions.handle(request, msg) tenant_dict = dict([(t.id, t.name) for t in tenants]) image.tenant_name = tenant_dict.get(image.owner)

commit_message:
Enable admin password complexity checks

Current OpenStack does not support user provided admin
password complexity checks. This spec propose to add
a trigger in configuration files to enable complexity
checks.

Change-Id: I2b6bd86d370a7ee8876a874a7bf897ec110161d6
Blueprint: password-complexity-check
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/41/192041/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================= Enable Password Complexity Checks ================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/password-complexity-check Problem description =================== When performing actions such as create instances, evacuate instances, rebuild instances, rescue instances and update instances' admin password. The complexity of user provided admin password has not been verified. This can cause security problems. Meanwhile, if the user dose not provide admin password, generate_password() in utils.py is used to generate an admin password. Generate_password() now uses two password symbol groups: default and easier, the default symbol group contains numbers, upper case letters and small case letters. the easier symbol group contains only numbers and upper case letters. The generated password is not complex enough and also can cause security problems. Use Cases ---------- Allowing admin user to set a trigger enables complexity checks for user provided password. And also a trigger to select complex admin password generation when password is not provided by user. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== 1. Add an option in configuration file informing whether password complexity check is enabled, add complexity check function in servers.py. When performing actions such as create instances, evacuate instances, rebuild instances, rescue instances and update instances' admin password. We will first look up this configure option and if complexity check is enabled, complexity checks will be performed, and if the provided password does not fulfil the requirement, an error will be thrown to inform the users. If this option has not been set, the operation will be same as it is now. 2. Add another option in configuration file informing whether to use complex auto-generated password or not. And add new symbol group: STRONGER_PASSWORD_SYMBOLS which contains numbers, upper case letters, lower case letters and also special characters such as `~!@#$%^&*()-_=+ and space. When this option is set, nova will generate password using STRONGER_PASSWORD_SYMBOLS symbol group and with longer password length. If this option is not set, the password will be generated using the default symbol group and default length. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None (changes must not impact the data model). REST API impact --------------- Add new exception. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zheng Zhenyu Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Add new configuration file options. * Add complexity check function. * Add new symbol group. * Add related test cases. * Add instructions in related doc files. Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== Instructions will be added in configuration guide. References ========== History =======

commit_message:
test cases for third party CI

PCI pass-through need third part CI to running test cases on
real HW. need create test cases, find place to hold the test
cases and share the test cases among all the third party CI.

Implements blueprint pci-test-cases-for-third-party-ci

Change-Id: Ieae7899e1e913f10715ee74427a5fc5ccd89c89b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/70/141270/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unsorted License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================ PCI test cases for third party CI ================================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/pci-test-cases-for-third-party-ci Provide the PCI test cases, enable them share among third party CI. Problem description =================== The existing feature PCI and SRIOV need to be fully tested by CI,but for now, running a tempest in a VM can not well provide a simulated PCI devices and iommu. Third party CI is a reasonable choice To enable third party CI, problems bellowing need be addressed: 1. What test cases should be created to covering the features 2. Where is the best place to hold the test cases 3. How third party CI running the specific test cases. Use Cases --------- Testing feature which need real HW to run. Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== Test cases should cover: 1. PCI pass-through basic testing: create, reboot, suspending and resume server with PCI devices allocated. 2. PCI pass-through resizing. 3. PCI pass-through pressure testing like allocation all devices cloud have, exhausting all pci devices. 4. PCI pass-through error handling and compute service rebooting. Where the test cases should located: the nova functional testing cases is the reasonable choice. new test cases use tempest-lib construct tempest like test cases. How running the specific test cases on a third party CI: nova unit test cases run_tests.sh could specify which test cases you want to running: ./run_tests.py functional/pci for each test cases there should some conditional decoration checking facility to check if the test cases should be running or not, just like tempest. Alternatives ------------ 1) The mocked libvirt or mocked qemu a) Not really verify the HW and hypervisor's functionality. b) Most likely fake libvirt is not only nova project, maybe need a new project. c) Fake a libvirt/qemu could be time consuming, testing for currently features is kind of urgent task. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Joe Gordon Yongli He Work Items ---------- 1. test cases for PCI pass-through using tempest-lib. assignee: Yongli He 2. third party CI test bed: assignee: Yongli He, Jiang Yu 3. bring up the tempest-lib assignee: Joe Gordon Dependencies ============ * Software versions: - Linux kernel: 3.10 or higher Testing ======= these test cases should be verified on real HW. Documentation Impact ==================== * Doc how third part CI can run these specify test cases. References ========== 1. faked libvirt alternative: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/139927/1 2. test cases proposal: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/139000/

commit_message:
Add separated policy rule for each v2.1 api

This bp is propose to add separated policy rule for each v3 api.
That will provide finer granularity to permission control and
consistent way to configure policy rule

Part of blueprint separated-policy-rule-v3-api

Change-Id: I0a8d43ac3ae56b65e598fc0dc0fab40a36ee1a00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/63/127863/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Add separated policy rule for each v2.1 api ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/separated-policy-rule-v3-api There are different ways to add policy rule for an API in the v2.1 extension. In some extensions, there is only one policy rule for all the APIs in that extension. In other extensions, there is a policy rule for each API in that extension. So this BP want to add policy rule for each v2.1 API, then we can get finer granularity to permission control and consistent way to configure policy rule for API. Problem description =================== 1. It didn't have finer granularity permission control in v2.1 API, This problem is same with this bp https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/aggregate-api-policy that want to resolve. 2. Hard to configure a policy rule for cloud operator. There isn't any document to mention that how to write an policy rule for each API. But there are some extensions only have one rule for all the API, and some extension is not. Cloud operator need check the source code to know How to write poliry rule for a specific API. User Cases ---------- * Use service api as example, operator only want to some users can check the service status, but didn't want those user can disable/enable some service. But service api only provides one policy rule for index, update, delete service. * Confuse for operator and developer, some of extensions have separated rule for each API, some of them is not. Project Priority ---------------- The kilo priorities list is currently not defined. However under the currently proposed list of priorities it would fall under "User Experience" as it significantly increases the ability for us to improve the Nova API. Proposed change =============== Add policy rule for each API in v2.1 API. Then it get finer granularity permission control. And Cloud Operator is easy to know how to write a policy rule. Because all the policy rule follow the pattern: [prefix]:[extension_name]:[action_name] Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- It will make compute more secure since the one who is granted on one action may not be authorized to execute other actions in same extension. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployer get finer granularity permission control of API and consistent way to write policy rule. If the deployer have changed default rules for extensions that added separated in this BP, deployer need update their rules into those new separated rules. Developer impact ---------------- When developer add new extension, developer should provide policy rule for each API, not share an policy rule for the API in that extension. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alex Xu <xuhj@linux.vnet.ibm.com> Other contributors: Ji Chen <jcjichen@cn.ibm.com> Work Items ---------- admin_password agents attach_interface cells console_auth_token console_output consoles create_backup deferred_delete evacuate flavor_access flavor_manage hosts hypervisors ips multinic remote_consoles rescue server_actions server_diagnostics server_metadata server_password services Working list: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/separated_policy_rule Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= For unittest, it will add to ensure the policy rule existed and works. For tempest, because of the difficulty of configuring policy in tempest, so it won't test in tempest. Documentation Impact ==================== For deployer, they can set policy rule for each API. References ========== None

commit_message:
Refactor of the Neutron network adapter

Refactor the network API-neutron adapter to improve neutron API usage,
reduce complexity of critical, frequently used methods and align with
current data practices in nova.

Change-Id: If98aa01031fcdfa46fd59a511f16175892a9baea
Blueprint: nova-neutron-refactor
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/13/131413/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Refactor of the Neutron network adapter ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-neutron-refactor Through accretion, the Network API adapter for Neutron has become prohibitively difficult to maintain, debug and extend. In order to improve interoperability of Nova and Neutron, this code must be refactored to: * Make it easier to understand. * Make it easier to test effectively. * Encourage extension through acceptable coding and design practices and idioms. Problem description =================== The majority of Network API adapter is currently contained in nova/network/neutronv2/api.py. The principle implementation class is API and is direct descendent of `nova.network.base_api.NetworkAPI`. The implementation code has some issues: * The implementation of critical principle methods are large and monolithic including a large number of potential code paths. Besides implementation, this makes it very difficult to create and maintain effective unit tests. * Data type and organization were simply extended to accomodate new requirements as opposed to transforming to more appopriate types. * Neutron client API calls are accompanied by try/catch blocks that must be translated to Nova exceptions. As features have been added, this code has been duplicated over several methods, increasing the risk that a translation will be missed. * Certain APIs methods have become entry points for logically divergent operations (i.e. candy machine interfaces). This is easily identifiable by the complexity and size of their implementation. * JSON request bodies for the Neutron REST API tend to be constructed in-place and repeatedly throughout the code. This is error prone, difficult and labor intensive to maintain and test. It is also difficult for developers with only passing familiar with the Neutron API to identify errors and modify code. .. note:: Efforts to modify or extend the python neutron client to create a higher level facade to hide REST request body formatting are under discussion. Use Cases ---------- None. Project Priority ----------------- This effort falls under the stability category. Proposed change =============== Resolving the issues requires a major refactoring of the existing Neutron implementation of Nova's Network API. The scale and scope of the refactoring is large and pervasive and can be interpreted as a rewrite. However, the existing implementation and API definition serve as a starting point and requirements reference. To avoid obstacles endemic to refactoring the current implementation in-place, this refactor will be appear as a forked re-implementation that replaces the current version through configuration. This refactor internally separates operations that are logically quite different but accessed through a single API method (e.g. allocate_for_instance). This refactor wraps Neutron client methods in a higher layer abstraction to allow API implementation to focus on logic instead of details of the Neutron REST API. The refactor will also address remaining mismatches between current Nova practices (e.g. using objects instead of dictionairies) reducing the number of Neutron specific cases in Nova. The refactor also introduces data model changes to support Nova/Neutron interoperability and future networking features. Changes to the Network API runtime signatures are expected and are to be incrementally introduced. Consideration will be given to extending the functionality of the existing Neutron API methods and, if necessary, adding new methods. Alternatives ------------ The main alternate approach considered is an ordered, stepwise refactoring spread across multiple phases. For example, * Phase 1: Code cleanup and reorganization and use the Neutron API more efficiently. * Phase 2: Apply patterns and improve implementation. * Phase 3: Introduce data model changes and make the API implementation compatible with the existing Nova-Network version. This is a more classic approach to refactoring and was the approach initially considered. After discussion and investigation, any potential merits of this approach are outweighed by current realities of development on Nova: * The amount of labor involved in simple refactorings such as "extract method" is dramatically increased by the state of the existing unit tests. The size of a single patch for a single refactor operation (e.g. extract method) would consequently be large. Large changes to the test suite increase the risk of broken tests, increase developer and reviewer burden without reducing risks of new bugs. To mitigate this, larger blocks of code might be modified at a time with a corresponding rewrite of entire blocks of tests - effectively blurring the lines between rewriting and refactoring. This is not without a cost however when considering the factors below. * An expected benefit of the phased approach are immediate gains in quality. This is primarily in reference to code quality, a developer facing concern, but also general stability and maintainability, which is a more widespread benefit. However, neither the code under modification nor the dependencies are static and there are typically several patches "in-flight" at a given moment. The risks of regressions, source code conflicts, and complexity of tracking down issues balances the benefits of refactoring critical pieces of code. * Without the larger context of the expected end result, patches are difficult to evaluate. Knowledge of both Nova and Neutron is not commonplace, implying a subset of available for reviewers. The cross-component nature of the code is also an obstacle to "getting good reviews". Patches that include all of the relevant context would be easier to digest and review effectively. * The phased approach introduces a targeting problem for changes that are currently in-flight or come up during a cycle. Are they introduced as patches against the current code, the refactoring-in-progress code or deferred to post refactoring? The decision would be case specific but any course of action comes with a certain degree of risk. The suggested approach would expect that changes are simply applied to the existing code and have to be ported to the in-flight refactoring. In essence, the changes affect on those working on the refactor. Data model impact ----------------- New data objects will be introduced to the data model to better support extension of networking related items. Data that is currently stored directly in instances or related metadata will be extracted to the new model. Existing network API implementations will be adapted to use these changes. REST API impact --------------- It is not expected that the REST API will be changed in this process. Future changes may be proposed however. The implementation of the Compute REST API is expected to change as special cases for Neutron configurations will become obsolete. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Users will need to explictly configure the new implementation in Nova in order to use it. Performance Impact ------------------ The refactoring includes profiling and rationalizing of Nova/Neutron interaction and reduction in redundant calls. Performance is not adversely affected and should be improved in some cases. Other deployer impact --------------------- It is expected that additional source files will be created. Deployment tools that are not wild card based in file selection will need to be modified to include the new files. Developer impact ---------------- Developers working with the existing code will be lightly impacted by incremental patches that land during the refactoring process. These patches primarily impact the Network API, the related data model and the consumers of both. The existing Neutron implementation will be adapted to supply implementations for these changes as much as possible to avoid loss of functionality. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Brent Eagles (beagles@redhat.com) is leading the refactoring of this code in this phase. One or more sponsors from the core teams should have direct involvement in an, at minimum, advisory capacity. Particularly: * Dan Smith - Nova: objects, data model and migration. * (interested neutron cores?) Primary assignee: * Brent Eagles beagles@redhat.com Work Items ---------- 1. Create repeatable profiling test cases for common use cases. 2. Verify and extend Nova network API functional tests. 3. Construct and verify new API implementation Dependencies ============ The relative stability of the networking API, as well as well as internal APIs of adjacent code (e.g. objects) as well as the neutron REST APIs. Testing ======= Additional functional tests may be required to provide sufficient rigor for validating the new implementation. Documentation Impact ==================== The refactored implementation will appear as an additional network backend API until such time that it can replace the current API implementation. A configuration to select the alternate implementation will need documentation. References ==========

commit_message:
Store console auth tokens in DB with object supported

DocImpact
Blueprint: store-console-tokens-in-db
Change-Id: I58d98500972665a5f670b7b15fd01f001f54d45f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/71/177671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support consoleauth service HA ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-console-auth-ha The consoleauth service doesn't support HA if without external memcache. Problem description =================== When running multiple consoleauth service without external memcache(each service has their own memchache), the console auth token will be cached in one of them, so the authentication will be failed if the console auth service happen don't save that token in its local memcache. Use Cases ---------- Admin want to deploy mutiple console auth service for HA. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Add new option DB backend to save console token. We add a new configure option 'auth_token_backend' for console auth service to indicate if they want to use DB as backend to save console auth token, that is to say we can have this configurable so if operator don't use console auth as HA mode, they can still choose to only use memcache as backend, so this will be flexiable to operator and it's no effect of performence cost at all compared to now. If have auth_token_backend=DB, we save a copy of console auth token in DB. By saving a copy of console auth token in data base, we can first check the token in local memcache, if don't find that token, then query it from data base again. Follow changes will be needed: * New sqlalchemy model will be created. * New sqlalchemy api will be created: * console_token_authorize: create a new row in DB. * console_token_get: query token by token name from DB. * console_token_delete_for_instance: delete tokens by given instance uuid. * console_token_delete_expired: delete all expried token from DB. * New object class ConsoleAuthToken will be added, it indicated an auth token: fileds will be as follows: fields = { 'id': fields.IntegerField(), 'token': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'console_type': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'host': fields.StringField(nullable=False), 'port': fields.IntegerField(nullable=False), 'internal_access_path': fields.StringField(nullable=True) 'instance_uuid': fields.UUIDField(nullable=False), 'access_url': fields.StringField(nullable=True), 'expires': fields.IntegerField(nullable=False), } * New conductor api/rpcapi will be added for DB access: * console_token_authorize * console_token_get * console_token_delete_for_instance * console_token_delete_expired * Add new periodic to delete expired tokens from DB: The periodic task will be help to delete expired auth tokens from DB every console_token_ttl. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- A new table will be created as: table('console_auth_tokens', meta, Column('created_at', DateTime), Column('updated_at', DateTime), Column('deleted_at', DateTime), Column('id', Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False), Column('token', String(255), nullable=False), Column('console_type', String(255), nullable=False), Column('host', String(255), nullable=False), Column('port', Integer, nullable=False), Column('internal_access_path', String(255)), Column('instance_uuid', String(36), nullable=False), Column('access_url', String(255)), Column('expires', Integer, nullable=False), Column('deleted', Integer), Index('console_auth_tokens_active_idx', 'deleted', 'expires'), UniqueConstraint('token', 'deleted', name='uniq_token_deleted'), mysql_engine='InnoDB', mysql_charset='utf8' ) REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- This change saved the console auth token in local database, so we need to take care about the security of database, and make sure this table will be not seen by other service. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ If operator configure to use auth_token_backend=DB: * Additional DB access will be called when called when doing authorize_console, additional DB access will be called when configure multiple service without using share memcache, in this case, memcache may failed, so need to query from DB. * A periodic task will be involved to do periodic removing expired token from DB, the interval will be console_token_ttl. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- New sqlalchemy api and conductor api will be involved, it will bump up version of conductor api. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: eliqiao <qiaoliyong@gmail.com> Work Items ---------- * Add a new table console_auth_tokens, sqlalchemy apis and ConsoleAuthToken object. * Add conductor console_auth_token apis. * Change console auth service to save a copy of auth token to database. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test case of conductor api and console auth service for multiple services will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== The operator can configure multiple console auth service for HA requirements. References ========== A WIP poc can be found: * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/177078/ * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/177144/ * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/177145/

commit_message:
Amend Wrap Neutron client calls spec

Updates the "Wrap Neutron client calls" spec to address feedback given
after it was merged.

(Original Change-Id: Iaaa298029e139690526a61de51b569dd8d34236d).

blueprint nova-neutron-refactor

Change-Id: I3fe4ef728c1410b438cdee36beccb449cc7d85bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/55/190855/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Openstack Network API is a basic, thin wrapper around the Neutron API. Providing a higher level wrapper around the Neutron API makes it easier implement and maintain the Nova/Neutron interaction.Additionally, operations conditionally require elevated permissions (e.g. admin tenant or specialized extensions) are provided through a separate class to avoid confusion. Using a factory method, the current tenant and available extensions are examined to determine if an new Neutron client instance with elevated permissions is required and initializes and instance accordingly. For example: :: class QueryClient(object): .... def get_networks(...) class UpdateClient(object): .... def update_port(...) def create_port(...) def get_updater(context): (Names are for illustrative purposes. Somebody is bound to have better names) * Seah Collins (Nova/Neutron liaison)This activity includes the design and implementation of the wrapper and associated tests. Use of the wrapper is introduced incrementally through the Nova/Neutron facade in separate changes.There is a dependency on changes due to the ongoing refactorings to NovaObjects covered in the liberty-objects blueprint, particularly conversion of the nova.network.model classes to NovaObjects.
deleted_lines: Openstack Network API is a basic, thin wrapper around the Neutron API. Direct use of the module's functionality has resulted in pervasive adaptive code throughout the API adapter implementation. The repetitive and occasionally opaque nature of this code makes the implementation difficult to debug and maintain. Providing higher level, Nova oriented abstractions by wrapping the existing client: * Makes it easier to implement readable implementations of the networking API implementation. * Allows knowledge of the functioning of the Neutron API to be captured in code for reuse by all developers, independent of their Neutron API expertise. This is maintainable, extensible and testable in itself. * Provides a natural boundary to hide neutron specific details such as: * thrown exceptions * JSON request and response translation* Maru Newby (Neutron) Primary assignee: * Brent Eagles beagles@redhat.com1. Create a class that provides higher level methods for neutron client. 2. Create tempest tests to exercise wrapper.None

commit_message:
Workflow to manage unauthorised resizing

There is some cases where switching from one flavor to an other
is not possible. The reason could be technical (incompatibility
between two computes) or strategy (strong separation between two
offers).

This means that flavors are linked together. One flavor could have a
list of compatible or incompatible flavors.

To solve this problem, a flavor could have a "type" and nova should
allow resizing only between the same flavor types.

Change-Id: Ic1941b5eb13122c43df4fe441b681b423681b047
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/45/182345/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Flavor Resize Restriction ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/flavor-resize-restriction Flavors could have incompatibility (technical, strategy/marketing...). - Technical: Two different architectures, two different hypervisors - Strategy/Marketing: Two offers with no possibility to switch from one to an other The need is to associate flavors together when resizing is possible and provide a clean error when it's not. Problem description =================== An instance can switch to any other flavor when resizing but flavors could have incompatibility each other. Use Cases ---------- An Operator could have different architecture (power8, x86) or different hypervisor (KVM, vSphere, Hyper-V), a flavor is attached to a type of architecture or hypervisor. Resizing to a new flavor should be possible only for same type of flavor. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== Posting to get preliminary feedback on the scope of this spec. Extra_specs could be used to describe a type a flavor. Every flavor with the same type should be compatible. This extra_spec should be available in the Glance metadata catalog definition. http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/glancemetadefcatalogapi.html Nova should check this information before running a resize order. This check could be done if the configuration says to do it with a new boolean entry in the configuration file like "strict_flavor_compatibility = true". Alternatives ------------ Still in extra_specs, for each flavors, describe a list of compatible flavors for resizing. This solution could be more precise and give posibility to do everything you want but it will be hard to maintaine. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- None Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== New boolean entry in /etc/nova/nova.conf: strict_flavor_compatibility References ========== None History ======= None .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced
