commit_message:
Fix the pep8 issues

The stackviz repo was recently moved into gerrit and the standard python
jobs were added on it. However there were some outstanding pep8 issue on
the repo which is blocking any changes. This commit fixes all of them.

Change-Id: I2d40ee965ba3166a580f16046fc741e05b54ac74

commit_message:
Add consistency group support to manila client

Adds support for recently implemented Manila features:
    * consistency groups
    * consistency group snapshots

Enables the client to support newly available APIs which support create,
update, read, and delete operations for consistency groups and
consistency group snapshots.

Implements bp: manila-client-consistency-groups

Change-Id: Ia2760156ab289f127fd7411a7b9a13a371f5129c

commit_message:
Do not use name attribute for path argument

The tests were using the name attribute for a path argument in
the resource test.  This is very confusing and unrelatistic.
We might use the parent name, but not the name of the resource
itself.

Change-Id: I26f0bd741e39b32501ef0624ec25829926df864d

commit_message:
Copy attributes in resource constructor

It seems like it would be a lot safer to copy the attributes
in the resource constructor rather than just using them.  This
way the resource can do what it wants with them without worrying
about messing anyone else up.

Change-Id: I004a7936243d5a585303c4b0da02163d0a6ab460

commit_message:
Ignore request with swift.source in env

swift.source in env indicates request
that originate in swift middleware as a side
effect of another client request.

These requests should not be metered, this
fix adds a check for swift.source in env
and avoids generating a metering event.

Change-Id: I2ecbde8667cc366b192a2248abc93d0936956978
Closes-bug: 1485711

commit_message:
iSCSI fix misleading Log warning on connect fail

This patch just changes the LOG.warning message
when we are iterating over the target_portals and trying
to do a connect/login.  When the connect/login fails,
we just log saying that the connect for that portal fails,
instead of log warning that ALL connects failed.

Change-Id: I4c35c5096eb15e47d306744d5ab1d1045c2ac319
Closes-Bug: 1489544

commit_message:
Add get_sandbox_key to utils.py

This patch adds get_sandbox_key, which takes the container ID as string
and returns the path to the netns file as string, to utils.py. This
patch also includes the unit test for it.

Change-Id: I931036337d16074b3aa4d5555ba2bf3d178c714f
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/09/223509/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os DOCKER_NETNS_BASE = '/var/run/docker/netns' def get_sandbox_key(container_id): """Returns a sandbox key constructed with the given container ID. :param container_id: the ID of the Docker container as string :returns: the constructed sandbox key as string """ return os.path.join(DOCKER_NETNS_BASE, container_id[:12])

Refactor tests/test_kuryr.py not to import objects but modules

This patch modifies tests/test_kuryr.py to import the modules instead of
the objects.

Change-Id: I30e6334f7a2b33462d16c065e67b27fe6e68c2c4
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Refactor controllers.py not to import objects but modules

This patch replaces the direct uses of objects with the modules to
adjust to the OpenStack style guide.

Change-Id: If43fb612a8e121ccc9cd298e3b2ee9158806252e
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/33/221033/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import flask import jsonschemafrom kuryr import constants return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['PLUGIN_ACTIVATE']) json_data = flask.request.get_json(force=True) jsonschema.validate(json_data, schemata.NETWORK_CREATE_SCHEMA) return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['SUCCESS']) json_data = flask.request.get_json(force=True) jsonschema.validate(json_data, schemata.NETWORK_DELETE_SCHEMA) return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['SUCCESS']) json_data = flask.request.get_json(force=True) jsonschema.validate(json_data, schemata.ENDPOINT_CREATE_SCHEMA) return flask.jsonify({'Interfaces': response_interfaces}) return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['ENDPOINT_OPER_INFO']) json_data = flask.request.get_json(force=True) jsonschema.validate(json_data, schemata.ENDPOINT_DELETE_SCHEMA) return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['SUCCESS']) return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['JOIN']) return flask.jsonify(constants.SCHEMA['SUCCESS'])

commit_message:
Switch the remaining jobs to Zanata

This moves the remaining jobs to pulling from Zanata, which ended up
only being the Manuals jobs and Horizon.

Change-Id: I0af0d625853301aa549ed2c117a0b27f9ff57e62

commit_message:
Add the validation for /NetworkDriver.DeleteEndpoint

This patch adds the validation for /NetworkDriver.DeleteEndpoint with
the JSON schema.

Change-Id: I836115ebf58c0d931ca018abddacccb8eaf10f99
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>

the JSON schema.

Change-Id: Iff00a237ca3dcc1404c12389fb7e81b07deb305e
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add the validation for /NetworkDriver.CreateNetwork

This patch adds the validation for /NetworkDriver.CreateNetwork with
the JSON schema.

This patch also introdueces the basic foundation for the following
validations with JSON schemata. The common part of the scheamta is
separated in commons.py and it's injected into each schema.

Change-Id: I1cd849db2eeadb03b4488e1842fbd22e62fff169
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/36/212136/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from jsonschema import validatefrom kuryr.schemata import NETWORK_CREATE_SCHEMA validate(json_data, NETWORK_CREATE_SCHEMA)
deleted_lines: # TODO(tfukushima): Add a validation of the JSON data for the network.

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.DeleteEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. The unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

When the requst to delete the Endpoint is invoked, Kuryr deletes the
two or three resources corresponds to the Endpoint in the process of the
endpoint creation, i.e., Neutron port, Neutron subnet ofthe IPv4 address
and/or Neutron subnet of the IPv6 address. Kuryr searches the resources
with the given NetworkID and deletes them all based on the assumption
there's no conflict with the NetworkIDs.

Kuryr tries to delete all the Neutron subnets which IDs are contained in
the Neutron port, however if the multiple Docker endpoints have the same
subnet CIDR, the subntes can be referred from the multiple ports created
with the different Docker endpoint IDs and they can't be deleted unless
they're not referred from any port. In this case we'll get 409 Conflict
as the response status code and the corresponding exceptions. Kuryr
catches the exceptions, log them and continue to proceed because it is
totally the normal case.

The operation should be atomic but in this patch they're not because
there's no transaction mechanism in python-neutronclien and the better
design is required in the future.

Change-Id: I4c94428c613094e758bd228f586cb73f507b5775
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Implement /NetworkDriver.DeleteEndpoint

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.DeleteEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. The unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

When the requst to delete the Endpoint is invoked, Kuryr deletes the
two or three resources corresponds to the Endpoint in the process of the
endpoint creation, i.e., Neutron port, Neutron subnet ofthe IPv4 address
and/or Neutron subnet of the IPv6 address. Kuryr searches the resources
with the given NetworkID and deletes them all based on the assumption
there's no conflict with the NetworkIDs.

Kuryr tries to delete all the Neutron subnets which IDs are contained in
the Neutron port, however if the multiple Docker endpoints have the same
subnet CIDR, the subntes can be referred from the multiple ports created
with the different Docker endpoint IDs and they can't be deleted unless
they're not referred from any port. In this case we'll get 409 Conflict
as the response status code and the corresponding exceptions. Kuryr
catches the exceptions, log them and continue to proceed because it is
totally the normal case.

The operation should be atomic but in this patch they're not because
there's no transaction mechanism in python-neutronclien and the better
design is required in the future.

Change-Id: I4c94428c613094e758bd228f586cb73f507b5775
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/53/210053/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Deletes Neutron Subnets and a Port with the given EndpointID. This function takes the following JSON data and delegates the actual endpoint deletion to the Neutron client mapping it into Subnet and Port. :: { "NetworkID": string, "EndpointID": string } See the following link for more details about the spec: https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/blob/master/docs/remote.md#delete-endpoint # noqa """ json_data = request.get_json(force=True) app.logger.debug("Received JSON data {0} for /NetworkDriver.DeleteEndpoint" .format(json_data)) network_id = json_data['NetworkID'] endpoint_id = json_data['EndpointID'] filtered_networks = app.neutron.list_networks(name=network_id) neutron_network_id = filtered_networks['networks'][0]['id'] filtered_subnets = app.neutron.list_subnets(network_id=neutron_network_id) filtered_subnets = [subnet for subnet in filtered_subnets['subnets'] if endpoint_id in subnet['name']] for subnet in filtered_subnets: app.neutron.delete_subnet(subnet['id']) filtered_ports = app.neutron.list_ports(network_id=neutron_network_id) filtered_ports = [port for port in filtered_ports['ports'] if endpoint_id in port['name']] for port in filtered_ports: app.neutron.delete_port(port['id'])

commit_message:
Add various tripleo repositories to the PROJECTS list

Tripleo CI uses these repositories and should be pulling them in
in a standard way.

Depends-On: I2cbfa5a00f8c5679ab422e89da143eef1fe3f8c1

Change-Id: I4e7a110e5aef03b446a0c617b41fded299b0f140

subject: Set owner to root for ipsec.secrets for LibreSwan
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-10 13:43:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/34d8b1c6a59b29276e0679d4502b12132871ebba', 'message': 'Set owner to root for ipsec.secrets for LibreSwan

LibreSwan requires that the permissions on ipsec.secrets explicitly
allow access. Since it is running as root and the file permissions are
set to 0600, the owner of the ipsec.secrets file must be set to root.
This patch adds the appropriate rootwrap filter and sets the owner of
ipsec.secrets to root.

Change-Id: I414b5d9285d7a3ba9d3132bce9d7d5e3af43c37f
Closes-Bug: #1493492

commit_message:
Set owner to root for ipsec.secrets for LibreSwan

LibreSwan runs as root and needs access to ipsec.secrets. Currently,
ipsec.secrets is not owned by root and has 0600 permissions. This patch
adds a rootwrap filter for the chown operation and sets the
ipsec.secrets ownership to root.

Change-Id: I414b5d9285d7a3ba9d3132bce9d7d5e3af43c37f
Closes-Bug: #1493492

commit_message:
Refactor verification for ZanataRestService

Rather than pass verify to each function that requires it, refactor
it down the stack into __init__. Now that we have moved to using
translate.o.o which has a trusted certificate, switch the default
to True.

Add a command-line argument --no-verify to create-zanata-xml to ease
testing against translate-dev.

Change-Id: I0f2314a8e82c3b7f1c96f28408c36ea1dd786e2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/39/222039/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Pin karma package to 0.12

Currently the karma package required is ^0.13.4, this is
greater than the maximum package expectation for gulp-karma.

This patch pins karma to ~0.12.0 which installs the latest
0.12.x package. This fixes the npm install error that was
seen prior to this patch.

Change-Id: I24c504cf5f5a8348ea9c8f9d550eda2aa2fb876d

commit_message:
Rename Manila CI jobs

Manila test behavior is dependent on job names, for
instance: if "multibackend" keyword is present in job name,
the job is configured with multibackend parameters.
Adding "multibackend" keyword to existing "no-share-servers"
and "scenario" jobs allows multibackend configuration to
be set for these jobs. Currently there is no interest in
running "no-share-servers" and "scenario" jobs as single
backend, so these job variants will no longer run.

Change-Id: I2faa9459b7eb91dac809f9fcdda918567a5ea454

commit_message:
zuul/layout: run more puppet-openstack-integration on more modules

Puppet OpenStack Integration testing is now deploying Glance, Nova,
Neutron, Tempest, Open-vSwitch.
So we want to gate these modules as non-voting and get feedback at how
the integration jobs behave.

Change-Id: Icc7fa42d76c3fc072221929868db6a38c37afbf4

commit_message:
gerrit/puppet: fix mistral & murano permissions

puppet-mistral and puppet-murano are part of OpenStack [1]
which means they should be managed by Puppet OpenStack group like other
modules.

This patch deletes specific Gerrit configuration for the two modules and
makes sure we use the same Gerrit file from other Puppet OpenStack
modules.

[1] http://governance.openstack.org/reference/projects/puppet-openstack.html

Change-Id: Icde952ee4c6dcb73d8fc667b8957dd8de01acba6

subject: Implement /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-06 17:34:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/41aac19595c3f9d743ab6fd0989cc85d1907ee95', 'message': 'Implement /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. This unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

libnetwork's Endpoint is mapped into Neutron's Subnets and Port. The
request to create an Endpoint contains the information of libnetwork's
Interfaces to be manged, however in Neutron there's no single resource
corresponds to the Endpoint.

Therefore Kuryr tires to break the Endpoint into the following three
pieces.

1. Subnet for Address property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given Address property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
2. Subnet for AddressIPv6 property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given AddressIPv6 property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
3. Port which MAC address is the same as MacAddress property in the
   request

To distinguish Subnets created in 1. and 2., Kuryr names them by the
given EndpointId with the postfixes comprised of the indiceof the
interfaces and the version of the IP addresses, i.e., "v4" or "v6". For
the Port, Kuryr gives the index and the prefix "port".

In the process 1. and 2., Kuryr doesn't specify the allocation list for
the addresses and it's the responsibility of Neutron to allocate the
appropriate set of the addresses.

In the latter workflow, where a container joins the network and be
assinged for the specific address, Neutron should pass the appropriated
IP addresses allocated in this phase.

Change-Id: I1798b3baff56e285059435f2b8620f36811b580f
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-10 14:54:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/80d8a846c3d62ad03aa44af9081290c68f19487b', 'message': 'Implement /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. This unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

libnetwork's Endpoint is mapped into Neutron's Subnets and Port. The
request to create an Endpoint contains the information of libnetwork's
Interfaces to be manged, however in Neutron there's no single resource
corresponds to the Endpoint.

Therefore Kuryr tires to break the Endpoint into the following three
pieces.

1. Subnet for Address property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given Address property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
2. Subnet for AddressIPv6 property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given AddressIPv6 property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
3. Port which MAC address is the same as MacAddress property in the
   request

To distinguish Subnets created in 1. and 2., Kuryr names them by the
given EndpointId with the postfixes comprised of the indiceof the
interfaces and the version of the IP addresses, i.e., "v4" or "v6". For
the Port, Kuryr gives the index and the prefix "port".

In the process 1. and 2., Kuryr doesn't specify the allocation list for
the addresses and it's the responsibility of Neutron to allocate the
appropriate set of the addresses.

In the latter workflow, where a container joins the network and be
assinged for the specific address, Neutron should pass the appropriated
IP addresses allocated in this phase.

Change-Id: I1798b3baff56e285059435f2b8620f36811b580f
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-11 09:20:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/768b80abebca5582745722bc72cd13d5c96c6b92', 'message': 'Implement /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. This unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

libnetwork's Endpoint is mapped into Neutron's Subnets and Port. The
request to create an Endpoint contains the information of libnetwork's
Interfaces to be manged, however in Neutron there's no single resource
corresponds to the Endpoint.

Therefore Kuryr tires to break the Endpoint into the following three
pieces.

1. Subnet for Address property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given Address property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
2. Subnet for AddressIPv6 property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given AddressIPv6 property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
3. Port which MAC address is the same as MacAddress property in the
   request

To distinguish Subnets created in 1. and 2., Kuryr names them by the
given EndpointId with the postfixes comprised of the indice of the
interfaces and the version of the IP addresses, i.e., "v4" or "v6". For
the Port, Kuryr gives the index and the prefix "port".

In the process 1. and 2., Kuryr doesn't specify the allocation list for
the addresses and it's the responsibility of Neutron to allocate the
appropriate set of the addresses.

In the latter workflow, where a container joins the network and be
assinged for the specific address, Neutron should pass the appropriate
IP addresses allocated in this phase.

Change-Id: I1798b3baff56e285059435f2b8620f36811b580f
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-09-07 15:04:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/08a77e31edeb9b0ddacf77e6d43c22a5f8ead2fb', 'message': 'Implement /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. This unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

libnetwork's Endpoint is mapped into Neutron's Subnets and Port. The
request to create an Endpoint contains the information of libnetwork's
Interfaces to be managed, however in Neutron there's no single resource
corresponds to the Endpoint.

Therefore Kuryr breaks the Endpoint into the following three pieces.

1. Subnet for Address property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given Address property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
2. Subnet for AddressIPv6 property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given AddressIPv6 property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
3. Port which MAC address is the same as MacAddress property in the
   request

To distinguish Neutorn sSbnets created in 1. and 2., Kuryr names them by
the given EndpointId with the their subnet addresses as the postfixes.
For the Neutron port, Kuryr gives the EndpointID with the index of the
interface and the postfix, "port". For instance, if Address, i.e.,
10.0.1.0/24, and AddressIPV6, i.e., fe80::f816:3eff:fe20:57c4/64, which
corresponding Neutron subnets don't exist are given in a request against
/NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint, the following subnets and a port will be
created.

* 2909d21a-9447-4f14-83be-46ed7c0aa386-10.0.1.0
* 2909d21a-9447-4f14-83be-46ed7c0aa386-fe80::
* 2909d21a-9447-4f14-83be-46ed7c0aa386-0-port

In the process 1. and 2., Kuryr doesn't specify the allocation list for
the addresses and it's the responsibility of Neutron to allocate an
appropriate set of the addresses.

In the latter workflow, where a container joins the network and be
assinged for the specific address, Kuryr binds the container with the
created port which IP address that is allocated in this phase.

This patch implements the following IPAM blueprint in Kuryr partially
except for retrieving the names of the default subnets from the config
file:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kuryr/+spec/ipam

Change-Id: I1798b3baff56e285059435f2b8620f36811b580f
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>

corresponding Neutron subnets don't exist are given in a request against
/NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint, the following subnets and a port will be
created.

* 98953db3f8e6628caf4a7cad3c866cb090654e3dee3e37206ad8c0a81355f1b7-10.0.1.0
* 98953db3f8e6628caf4a7cad3c866cb090654e3dee3e37206ad8c0a81355f1b7-fe80::
* 98953db3f8e6628caf4a7cad3c866cb090654e3dee3e37206ad8c0a81355f1b7-0-port

In the process 1. and 2., Kuryr doesn't specify the allocation list for
the addresses and it's the responsibility of Neutron to allocate an
appropriate set of the addresses.

In the latter workflow, where a container joins the network and be
assinged for the specific address, Kuryr binds the container with the
created port which IP address that is allocated in this phase.

This patch implements the following IPAM blueprint in Kuryr partially
except for retrieving the names of the default subnets from the config
file:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kuryr/+spec/ipam

commit_message:
Implement /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint

This patch replaces the mocked version of /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint
with the actual Neutron call. This unit test for the endpoint is also
implemented.

libnetwork's Endpoint is mapped into Neutron's subnets and port. The
request to create an Endpoint contains the information of libnetwork's
Interfaces to be managed, however in Neutron there's no single resource
corresponds to the Endpoint.

Therefore Kuryr breaks the Endpoint into the following three pieces.

1. Subnet for Address property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given Address property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
2. Subnet for AddressIPv6 property in the request
   - Kuryr passes the given AddressIPv6 property to CIDR for the request
     against Neutron API as it is
3. Port which MAC address is the same as MacAddress property in the
   request

To distinguish Neutorn subnets created in 1. and 2., Kuryr names them by
the given EndpointId with the their subnet addresses as the postfixes.
For the Neutron port, Kuryr gives the EndpointID with the index of the
interface and the postfix, "port". For instance, if Address, i.e.,
10.0.1.1/24, and AddressIPV6, i.e., fe80::f816:3eff:fe20:57c4/64, which
corresponding Neutron subnets don't exist are given in a request against
/NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint, the following subnets and a port will be
created.

* 98953db3f8e6628caf4a7cad3c866cb090654e3dee3e37206ad8c0a81355f1b7-10.0.1.0
* 98953db3f8e6628caf4a7cad3c866cb090654e3dee3e37206ad8c0a81355f1b7-fe80::
* 98953db3f8e6628caf4a7cad3c866cb090654e3dee3e37206ad8c0a81355f1b7-0-port

In the process 1. and 2., Kuryr doesn't specify the allocation list for
the addresses and it's the responsibility of Neutron to allocate an
appropriate set of the addresses.

In the latter workflow, where a container joins the network and be
assinged for the specific address, Kuryr binds the container with the
created port which IP address that is allocated in this phase.

This patch implements the following IPAM blueprint in Kuryr partially
except for retrieving the names of the default subnets from the config
file:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kuryr/+spec/ipam

Change-Id: I1798b3baff56e285059435f2b8620f36811b580f
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr refs/changes/52/210052/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Creates new Neutron Subnets and a Port with the given EndpointID. This function takes the following JSON data and delegates the actual endpoint creation to the Neutron client mapping it into Subnet and Port. :: { "NetworkID": string, "EndpointID": string, "Options": { ... }, "Interfaces": [{ "ID": int, "Address": string, "AddressIPv6": string, "MacAddress": string }, ...] } See the following link for more details about the spec: https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/blob/master/docs/remote.md#create-endpoint # noqa """ json_data = request.get_json(force=True) app.logger.debug("Received JSON data {0} for /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint" .format(json_data)) network_id = json_data['NetworkID'] endpoint_id = json_data['EndpointID'] filtered_networks = app.neutron.list_networks(name=network_id) neutron_network_id = filtered_networks['networks'][0]['id'] interfaces = json_data['Interfaces'] response_interfaces = [] for interface in interfaces: # v4 and v6 Subnets for bulk creation. subnets = [] interface_id = interface['ID'] interface_ipv4 = interface['Address'] interface_ipv6 = interface['AddressIPv6'] interface_mac = interface['MacAddress'] if interface_ipv4: subnets.append({ 'name': '-'.join([endpoint_id, str(interface_id), 'v4']), 'network_id': neutron_network_id, 'ip_version': 4, 'cidr': interface_ipv4, }) if interface_ipv6: subnets.append({ 'name': '-'.join([endpoint_id, str(interface_id), 'v6']), 'network_id': neutron_network_id, 'ip_version': 6, 'cidr': interface_ipv6, }) # Bulk create operation of subnets app.neutron.create_subnet({'subnets': subnets}) port = { 'name': '-'.join([endpoint_id, str(interface_id), 'port']), 'admin_state_up': True, 'mac_address': interface_mac, 'network_id': neutron_network_id, } app.neutron.create_port({'port': port}) response_interfaces.append({ 'ID': interface_id, 'Address': interface_ipv4, 'AddressIPv6': interface_ipv6, 'MacAddress': interface_mac }) return jsonify({'Interfaces': response_interfaces})

Change translations proposal topic for zanata

Translations proposals are being moved to being submitted by Zanata rather than
Transifex, reflect this in the Gerrit topic.

Change-Id: I9bd7dc8c6cd761cdcd50b7ec0dcd34e57b253f47

commit_message:
Change ACL for puppet-murano to puppet-modules

In this commit rights to manage puppet-murano module is given to
puppet-openstack groups. Previously puppet-murano core group was
responsible for puppet-murano module per agreement with
Puppet Modules PTL - Emilien Macchi [1].

Reference:
[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/067260.html

Change-Id: Iaa01778ddcf00ae3e4d38051b42f6fe9fcbdb256

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/84/223584/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Currently, if you make changes in an already created environment that can affect target images created by the image-based provisioning system (for example, changes in repositories list) after your environment resets, these changes may not be applied during a new deployment. To solve the problem, manually remove a target image on Fuel Master node after an environment resets and before you redeploy it: .. code-block:: bash ENV_ID=1 find /var/www/nailgun/targetimages/ -name "env_$ENV_ID_*" -delete where ``ENV_ID`` is the ID of an OpenStack environment. See `1485997 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1485997>`_.

commit_message:
Stop pushing to Transifex

This removes the code from all four upstream_translation_* scripts
that pushes new .pot files up to Transifex, and forces the comments
around them to be in line.

This leaves Transifex setup in place for the moment, since the
propose jobs that pull from Transifex are still utilising it.

Change-Id: I702e6073f92faaa79a7aa53c44022f9e437721af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/43/222443/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The Zanata client works out what to send based on the zanata.xml file. zanata-cli -B -e push
deleted_lines: # Push .pot changes to transifex # Transifex project name does not include "." tx_project=${PROJECT/\./} # Only push if there is actual content in the file. We check # that the file contains at least one non-empty msgid string. if grep -q 'msgid "[^"]' ${PROJECT}/locale/${PROJECT}.pot ; then tx --debug --traceback push -s \ -r ${tx_project}.${tx_project}-translations fi for level in $LEVELS ; do # Only push if there is actual content in the file. We check # that the file contains at least one non-empty msgid string. if grep -q 'msgid "[^"]' ${PROJECT}/locale/${PROJECT}-log-${level}.pot then tx --debug --traceback push -s \ -r ${tx_project}.${tx_project}-log-${level}-translations fi done # The Zanata client works out what to send based on the XML file, push if # we have one. if [ -f zanata.xml ]; then zanata-cli -B -e push fi

commit_message:
Log a message when cant find multipath device

If we couldnt find a multipath device we will now log a debug message
explaining as much. This can be helpful when troubleshooting issues with
multipath configurations and connections.

Change-Id: Ia41f65478df67d5ff4857314aa749cbf5cdc89d0
Closes-Bug: #1493962
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/13/221913/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.debug("Unable to find multipath device name for " "host_device %(device)s. Only using path %(device)s " "for volume.", {'device': host_device}) LOG.debug("Unable to find multipath device name for " "host_device %(device)s. Using path " "%(device)s for volume.", {'device': self.host_device})

commit_message:
Add new bond propertiew configuration:

New properties are:
* downdelay
* updelay
* ad_select

Also implemented:
* improved tests
* replace some iproute() to corresponded class methods
* modifyed arping arguments
* move some interface-related methods to InterfaceToolset base class

implementation progress:
+ l23_stored_config_for LNX-ubuntu
+ l23_stored_config_for OVS-ubuntu
- l23_stored_config_for LNX-centos
- l23_stored_config_for OVS-centos
+ runtime configuration for LNX
+ runtime configuration for OVS

Change-Id: I3c144f410c29c114c7976a43f5fd00967ae601a4

commit_message:
Fixed issue with rabbit_ha_queues parameter

We need to configure rabbit_ha_queues = True only if we have
more than 1 RabbitMQ host. In we have one RabbitMQ host we need to
set rabbit_ha_queues = False.
We also need to use one pattern for configuration of this parameter
for different OpenStack components.

Also fixed issue with rabbit_hosts parameter, because we should initialize
it with array, not with string or boolen value.

Change-Id: I6eec853c1462579e89e53f5dece4272bb6d6a8e8
Closes-Bug: #1470054
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-sahara refs/changes/23/197023/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $rabbit_ha_queues = undef, if $rabbit_ha_queues == undef { if size($rabbit_hosts) > 1 { sahara_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_ha_queues': value => true } } else { sahara_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_ha_queues': value => false } } } else { sahara_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_ha_queues': value => $rabbit_ha_queues } }

commit_message:
[spec] Scenario to compose multiple scenarios

This will make it easy to chain multiple scenarios together, using the
resources created in previous scenarios to create very complex tasks
without writing code.

Change-Id: I2510d5ed0429687feb59173fc007a700047faa32
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/62/215762/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================== Scenario to Compose Multiple Scenarios ======================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/rally/+spec/compose-scenario This spec describes adding a "Compose" scenario that lets the user easily chain multiple existing scenarios together in sequence, using the return values of one scenario in subsequent scenarios. The entire chain would be treated as a single iteration. Problem description =================== Currently there is no easy way to run a more detailed benchmark that involves multiple steps, short of writing your own scenario. In many cases, scenarios that are already written provide building blocks that could be reused. For instance, a user in ``#openstack-rally`` asked: I'm trying to use rally to create a situation where I can create one private neutron network, attach several VMs to it, followed by create another network, attach VMs to that... and keep going. The solution is to write a custom scenario, but it could potentially be much easier to just chain together the existing ``NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_subnets`` and ``NovaServers.boot_and_delete_multiple_servers`` scenarios. Proposed change =============== There are three parts to this change: #. First, all existing scenarios must return the resources they create so that they can be reused. Many scenarios will not return anything at all since they only list existing resources or delete everything they create. #. Next, add a new core (i.e., not OpenStack plugin) scenario, ``Compose.compose`` that takes a single argument, ``scenarios``, which is a list of scenario names and arguments. #. Create and document a mini-language for reusing return values from previous scenarios. An example might look like: .. code-block:: yaml Compose.compose: - args: scenarios: - NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_subnets: {} - NovaServers.boot_and_delete_multiple_servers: flavor: name: m1.medium image: name: cirros-0.3.4-x86_64-uec count: 10 nics: - net-id: $get(NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_subnets.network.id) runner: type: "constant" times: 10 concurrency: 2 context: users: tenants: 3 users_per_tenant: 2 This would create a network, router, and subnet; then create 10 instances attached to the network. Things to note: * ``runner`` and ``context`` are only specified once, for the ``Compose.compose`` scenario itself. * The value of each sub-scenario is the set of ``args`` passed to that scenario. * The value of ``net-id`` uses the special token ``$get()`` token, which will be interpreted by ``Compose.compose``. Its value is a query, based on the language used by tools like jq and shyaml, to get the ``id`` of the network created by ``NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_subnets``. * This assumes that the return value of ``NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_subnets`` will be a dict or named tuple, e.g., something like: .. code-block:: python return {"network": network, "router": router, "subnets": subnets} This would be expected as a best practice for scenarios that need to return multiple data (rather than, say, a simple tuple). Alternatives ------------ Instead of a new ``Compose.compose`` scenario, this could be added as a new feature such that Rally itself supported chaining multiple scenarios. That requires a new schema for task files, though, and it isn't clear what the user would name a composed scenario. (Doing this with a scenario makes it obvious: ``Compose.compose``.) Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stpierre Work Items ---------- This can be done in three steps: #. Modify all existing scenarios that create (and retain) resources to return those resources in a sane fashion. #. Find or create and document a mini-language for querying data from the return values. We may be able to reuse code from shyaml, or find an existing library for this. #. Write the ``Compose.compose`` scenario. Some runner refactoring may be necessary to avoid duplicating code between the runners and ``Compose.compose``. Dependencies ============ None

commit_message:
Add retries to the url connectivity checker

Change-Id: Ifa8bfd6e954b085e049146faea42ac47ea955446
Closes-Bug: 1490562
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/06/219306/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: debug 'Call: url_available' raise Puppet::ParseError, "Invalid url type passed to the url_available function. Must be of type String or Hash." debug "Unable to parse proxy settings from: '#{http_proxy}', will ignore proxy setting. Error: '#{e}'" message = nil retry_count = 3 debug "Checking: #{uri}" Timeout::timeout(180) do http.request(request) message = "ERROR: Unable to fetch url: '#{uri}', error: '#{e.message}'. Please verify node connectivity to this URL, or remove it from the settings page if it is invalid." retry_count -= 1 if retry_count >= 1 debug message retry else raise Puppet::Error, message end
deleted_lines: raise Puppet::ParseError, "Invalid url type passed to the url_available function. Must be of type String or Hash." puts "Unable to parse proxy settings from '#{http_proxy}', will ignore proxy setting. Error '#{e}'" puts "Checking #{uri}" out = Timeout::timeout(180) do response = http.request(request) rescue OpenURI::HTTPError => error raise Puppet::Error, "ERROR: Unable to fetch url '#{uri}', error '#{error.io}'. Please verify node connectivity to this URL, or remove it from the settings page if it is invalid." raise Puppet::Error, "ERROR: Unable to fetch url '#{uri}', error '#{e}'. Please verify node connectivity to this URL, or remove it from the settings page if it is invalid."

commit_message:
Fix cli.base.execute with py34

In python3, the command must be a string not bytes.

Also all tempest_lib assert tools expected the result is a str.
But in python subprocess stdout/stderr returns bytes
To fix that we decode it with the fsencoding.

Change-Id: Id5b2e5d75f2c881cd2a3fff216126f6529dccef3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib refs/changes/70/218870/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six if six.PY2: cmd = cmd.encode('utf-8') cmd = shlex.split(cmd)

added_lines: only the old ones. The ``drop_flows_on_start`` option that manages a graceful OVS agent restart is now set to False by default. See `LP1383674`_ and `LP1483253`_. * The logging of Neutron agent heartbeats is now available to troubleshoot problems with a cluster if any. See `LP1453978`_. * A reload operation is added to Neutron L3 agent resource to prevent external connectivity interruption while disabling or enabling the agent (using ``pcs resource enable/disable p_neutron-*-agent``). Also, the patch updates the DHCP agent resource to keep consistency. See `LP1464817`_. * Previously ``gre`` segmentation type was allowed only if you set a specific option in the `astute.yaml` file. Now, you can deploy Neutron with ``gre`` along with ``vxlan`` segmentation type. See `LP1485920`_. * Neutron now supports an automatic cleanup of empty L3/DHCP namespaces after you remove resources. This option is enabled by default. See `LP1458633`_. Known issues ++++++++++++ * Instances' metadata on CentOS 6.6 cloud images with cloud-init 0.7.5 packages may be unset in Neutron environments. When an environment is deployed with one of the Neutron topologies and CentOS 6.6 cloud images are used, instances may be unreachable via SSH due to a cloud-init failure. It happens because users' keypairs and the rest of configuration data may not be set correctly. See `LP1406286`_... _`LP1383674`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1383674 .. _`LP1483253`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1483253 .. _`LP1453978`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/mos/7.0.x/+bug/1453978 .. _`LP1464817`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1464817 .. _`LP1485920`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/+bug/1485920 .. _`LP1458633`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/mos/7.0.x/+bug/1458633 .. _`LP1406286`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/mos/7.0.x/+bug/1406286

commit_message:
Allow updating networks after deployment

Since user can add new nodes for already deployed
cluster he also should be able to change already created
networks for it.
  * Extended list of states of cluster when updating of networks is enabled
  * Added check for conflicts of new IP-ranges with already allocated IPs
  * Field 'meta' of Network DB-model was made mutable
  * Fixed logic of using flag 'use_gateway' from network metadata
  * Added tests for new functionality

Change-Id: I9cc77a63b9b6695eb0639b8dbf9e42607b60287f
Closes-bug: #1472651

added_lines: import copy def test_cluster_locking_during_deployment(self): cluster_kwargs={'status': CLUSTER_STATUSES.deployment}, {'pending_addition': False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.deploying}, {'pending_addition': False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.deploying}, {'pending_addition': False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.deploying}]) def test_networks_update_after_deployment(self): self.env.create( cluster_kwargs={'status': CLUSTER_STATUSES.operational}, nodes_kwargs=[ {'pending_addition': False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.ready}, {'pending_addition': False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.ready}, {'pending_deletion': False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.ready}]) test_nets = self.env.nova_networks_get( self.env.clusters[0].id).json_body test_network_params = copy.deepcopy(test_nets['networking_parameters']) # change something from 'networking_parameters' test_nets['networking_parameters']['dns_nameservers'] = \ ['one.dns', 'two.dns'] test_network_name = test_nets['networks'][0]['name'] test_network_ranges = [[u'1.1.1.2', u'1.1.1.5']] test_nets['networks'][0]['ip_ranges'] = test_network_ranges test_nets['networks'][0]['cidr'] = u'1.1.1.0/24' # self.assertEqual(test_nets, None) resp_nova_net = self.env.nova_networks_put( self.env.clusters[0].id, test_nets) self.assertEqual(resp_nova_net.status_code, 200) new_nets = self.env.nova_networks_get( self.env.clusters[0].id).json_body modified_net = filter(lambda x: x['name'] == test_network_name, new_nets['networks'])[0] self.assertEqual(test_network_ranges, modified_net['ip_ranges']) # test that networking_parameters were not changed self.assertDictEqual(test_network_params, new_nets['networking_parameters'])
deleted_lines: def test_cluster_locking_after_deployment(self): cluster_kwargs={'status': CLUSTER_STATUSES.operational}, {"pending_addition": False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.ready}, {"pending_addition": False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.ready}, {"pending_deletion": False, 'status': NODE_STATUSES.ready}])

commit_message:
puppet-murano: Initial commit

This is the initial commit for puppet-murano.
It has been automatically generated using cookiecutter[1] and msync[2]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstack-cookiecutter
[2] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-modulesync-configs

Change-Id: I1d1e17825d8c083d75f5b409a1e64cee391435b9

commit_message:
Prepare Tempest and run smoke

Still hacking on the patch to make it pass trusty systems.

* Create 2 flavors, used by Tempest Compute tests
* Create 'public' network, used by Tempest Compute tests for floating-ip
* Configure Tempest to be aware about the 2 created flavors refs
* Configure Tempest to be aware about the public network
* Add some Puppet Exec code that prepare virtual bridging to reach floating IPs
* Add scenario parameters
* Run Smoke suite that includes 2 scenarios & some important API tests.
* Pin python-netaddr on ubuntu so we can test floating-IP.

Change-Id: Iebb83e110fbb0c072f06b3ca2ad84987e0efe3a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/52/217352/34 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nova_available => true, neutron_available => true, flavor_ref => '42', flavor_ref_alt => '84',

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-09 16:52:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard/commit/7e2da1d3f95ff43ab0a6b1b5742d4c193ca9cf56', 'message': "Provide tenant name information

Currently if there are several packages with same name
from different tenant, it's impossible to recognize whitch package
belongs to which tenant.
This commit adds new field to Package Definitions table, that
provides this information.

Non-admin user has no rights to get this information. so this field is
hidden. But it's not a problem, since regular user
is not allowed to modify foriegn packages.

commit_message:
Provide tenant name information

Currently if there are several packages with same name
from different tenant, it's impossible to recognize whitch package
belongs to which tenant.
This commit adds new field to Package Definitions table, that
provides this information.

Non-admin user has no rights to get this information. so this field is
hidden. But it's not a problem, since regular user
is not allowed to modify foriegn packages.
Corresponding tests were updated and refactored a little bit
to keep column order in one place.

Change-Id: Iec796c7eff3d53a1dd34e134aca7ceb3c036c037
Closes-Bug: #1488448
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/78/221878/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack_dashboard.api import keystone # Add information about project tenant for admin user if self.request.user.is_superuser: try: tenants, _more = keystone.tenant_list(self.request) except Exception: exceptions.handle(self.request, _("Unable to retrieve project list.")) tenent_name_by_id = {tenant.id: tenant.name for tenant in tenants} for i, p in enumerate(packages): if p.owner_id in tenent_name_by_id.keys(): packages[i].tenant_name = tenent_name_by_id[p.owner_id]

commit_message:
Fix Ceilosca deployer script to clear env

If Ceilosca script fails or is interrupted
after devstack.yml playbook, specifically
after setting up monasca cli creds in default
env, re-running ceilosca script fails when setting
up devstack since devstack tries to use OS_*
vars in the env and fails when trying to use
monasca (mini-mon) credentials.

This fixes the deployer script to clear the env
variables before running devstack.

Change-Id: Ia9fe6dc96f6f93396b6d68965f3b2e510ee2f329
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-ceilometer refs/changes/66/222966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: clear_env() { unset OS_USERNAME OS_PASSWORD OS_PROJECT_NAME OS_AUTH_URL }clear_env

commit_message:
Fix running when empty config file

Bandit would error with a traceback when the config file was empty.
Bandit doesn't have a problem with a non-empty config file that
contains a bunch of invalid keys, so it could just work with an
empty config file.

Change-Id: I7fd912076aa89c15b6b9400d3a784c8afdf3278d
Closes-Bug: 1492068

commit_message:
Fix mistakes in comments

Each can only delete an aggregate by API,
so, change 'aggregates' to 'aggregate'

Also, change 'Set a aggregate metadata' to
'Set aggregate metadata'

Change-Id: Ieb4a8b2445678da8741794613aede948ba51e5ce

commit_message:
do not generate meter links on resource-list

meter links are not accessible via resource_list and add significant
overhead to query. we shouldn't generate these anymore. this patch is
slightly different from master as this does not disable meter_links
by default to maintain existing functionality.

Change-Id: Ib20f410a70171aa09e4ebbbb748a5ce495fc6a43
Closes-Bug: #1493400

commit_message:
Fixes missing socket attribute error during init_poolmanager

On Windows, the 'socket' python module does not contain the
attributes TCP_KEEPCNT or TCP_KEEPINTVL, causing services
consuming the library to malfunction.

Adds conditionals for adding the mentioned socket attributes
to the socket options.

socket.SIO_KEEPALIVE_VALS cannot be added as a socket option
for Windows, as there is another way entirely to enable that
option.

Change-Id: I2e9746ae65400bbd23c3b48dfc3167de9eb66494
Partial-Bug: #1483696
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/86/211686/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if hasattr(socket, 'TCP_KEEPCNT'): socket_options += [ # Set the maximum number of keep-alive probes (socket.IPPROTO_TCP, socket.TCP_KEEPCNT, 4) ] if hasattr(socket, 'TCP_KEEPINTVL'): socket_options += [ # Send keep-alive probes every 15 seconds (socket.IPPROTO_TCP, socket.TCP_KEEPINTVL, 15) ]
deleted_lines: # Set the maximum number of keep-alive probes (socket.IPPROTO_TCP, socket.TCP_KEEPCNT, 4), # Send keep-alive probes every 15 seconds (socket.IPPROTO_TCP, socket.TCP_KEEPINTVL, 15),

commit_message:
Change the word for clarity

settable => configurable
and moves the word "only"

This is a suggestion from CLI reference review.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/221996/1
The CLI reference generation tool generates
from command help message.

commit_message:
Improve the rest api a bit

This commit adds some more methods to the api to add additional query
support. It adds other top level queries for tests and test runs it
then adds some routes for filtered tests and test_runs by a specific
run. It also adds a query to get a list of runs for a specific
build_name (aka a job name).

Change-Id: Ib0376f39819676b3eb33a2693fad9ddf85aaa509
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/87/223387/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @app.route('/build_name/<string:build_name>/runs', methods=['GET']) def get_runs_from_build_name(build_name): global Session session = Session() db_runs = api.get_runs_by_key_value('build_name', build_name, session) runs = [run.to_dict() for run in db_runs] return flask.jsonify({'runs': runs}) @app.route('/run/<string:run_id>/tests', methods=['GET']) def get_tests_from_run(run_id): global Session session = Session() db_tests = api.get_tests_from_run_id(run_id, session) tests = [test.to_dict() for test in db_tests] return flask.jsonify({'tests': tests}) @app.route('/run/<string:run_id>/test_runs', methods=['GET']) def get_run_test_runs(run_id): global Session session = Session() db_test_runs = api.get_tests_run_dicts_from_run_id(run_id, session) return flask.jsonift(db_test_runs) @app.route('/tests', methods=['GET']) def get_tests(): global Session session = Session() db_tests = api.get_all_tests(session) tests = [test.to_dict() for test in db_tests] return flask.jsonify({'tests': tests}) @app.route('/test_runs', methods=['GET']) def get_test_runs(): global Session session = Session() db_test_runs = api.get_all_test_runs(session) test_runs = [test_run.to_dict() for test_run in db_test_runs] return flask.jsonify({'test_runs': test_runs})

commit_message:
Use PROJECT instead of TENANT

Keystone has long moved to using `PROJECT` instead of `TENANT`. This
patch aligns glanceclient with that in a backwards compatible way.
Scripts still using older versions of keystone or old versions of `rc`
files will still work.

Change-Id: I44eee913811c23b04c9216fdadb828de000c2655
Closes-bug: #1495940

commit_message:
Do not allow exceptions to kill powervm agent

Previously, we only allowed 3 unhandled exceptions to occur before letting
the powervm neutron agent die.  This changeset is to make the agent more
robust and handle an unlimited number of exceptions, sleeping a configurable
number of seconds if one is caught.

Change-Id: Ie249b34db7ff7831485a1618ae9474e87a5a034c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-powervm refs/changes/02/223102/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.i18n import _, _LE cfg.IntOpt('exception_interval', default=5, help=_("The number of seconds agent will wait between " "polling when exception is caught")), except Exception as e: # sleep for a while and re-loop time.sleep(ACONF.exception_interval)
deleted_lines: from neutron.i18n import _, _LW, _LE succesive_exceptions = 0 # If the code reached this point, the successive exceptions # can be reset to 0. succesive_exceptions = 0 except Exception as e: # The agent should retry a few times, in case something # bubbled up. A successful provision loop will reset the # timer. # # Note that the exception timer is not reset if there are no # provisions. That is because 99% of the errors will occur # in the provision path. So we only reset the error when # a successful provision has occurred (otherwise we'd never # hit the exception limit). succesive_exceptions += 1 if succesive_exceptions == 3: LOG.error(_LE("Multiple exceptions have been " "encountered. The agent is unable to " "proceed. Exiting.")) raise else: LOG.warn(_LW("Error has been encountered and logged. The " "agent will retry again."))

commit_message:
Adding Ryan Moats' candidacy for Neutron

Change-Id: I97f4925ebc138831ad3530e694d14925cbe2814d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/26/223326/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: I'd like to announce my candidacy for the Mitaka cycle as Neutron PTL. While not currently a Neutron core, I've been looking at hard at Neutron for several cycles now and I feel that while we've accomplished a great deal, more consolidation at this point will be desirable. Therefore, if elected, my goals for the Mitaka cycle will be: 1. Continue the decomposition efforts that Kyle has championed up through the Liberty cycle. 2. Improve the performance and reliability of existing reference solutions so that operators can be more confident when deploying neutron. 3. Like Liberty, we have a large list of new items for the design summit [1], which we will work to pare down into items that can be delivered in Mitaka Thanks, Ryan Moats IRC handle: regXboi

commit_message:
Adding 'Joshua Harlow' candidacy for for 'oslo'

Change-Id: Ic0b93b5a6be324bf362ceb051f6348c94bbe736e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/46/223346/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Howdy folks, I'd like to propose myself for oslo PTL for the mitaka cycle, For those that don't know me I've been involved in openstack for ~4 years, Have worked at yahoo! for ~7 years, ~4 of the last years have been getting openstack adopted in yahoo! (where it is now used by everyone, and is a common word/name/project all employees know about, quite a change from when 3 other engineers and myself started investigating it 4 years ago). It has been quite the journey (for myself, others and yahoo! in general) and I've been pretty active in oslo for ~2 years so I thought it might be a good time to try to run and see how I can help in a PTL role (this also ensures nobody else in oslo-core burns out). I contribute to many projects (inside and outside of openstack): - http://stackalytics.com/report/users/harlowja Created/maintain/co-maintain/contributor/core to the following: (not directly openstack, generally useful to all) - https://kazoo.readthedocs.org - https://redis-py.readthedocs.org - https://cloudinit.readthedocs.org - https://fasteners.readthedocs.org - https://pymemcache.readthedocs.org - https://pypi.python.org/pypi/zake - https://pypi.python.org/pypi/doc8 - https://pypi.python.org/pypi/retrying (mainly created for usage by openstack, but not limited to) - https://anvil.readthedocs.org - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/futurist/ - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/automaton/ - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/debtcollector/ - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/taskflow/ - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tooz/ (created for usage by openstack) - oslo.messaging - oslo.utils - oslo.serialization - oslo.service - (all the other 'oslo.*' libraries) (and more...) I feel I can help bring a unique viewpoint to oslo and openstack in general; one of increasing exposure and general usefulness of oslo libraries outside of openstack; fostering community inside and outside and continuing to make oslo and openstack the best it can be. Some of the things that I would like to focus on (not inclusive of all the things): - Increasing outreach to consuming projects so that they can benefit from the oslo libraries, code and knowledge (and patterns) that have been built up by these libraries; perhaps some kind of bi-weekly blog about oslo? - Improving our outreach to others in the wider world (even ones not in the big tent); the python community is a big world and it'd be great to make sure we do our part there as well. - Being jolly. - Asking the hard questions. Thanks for considering me, -Joshua Harlow

Change-Id: I232332354519da53d77ae56442e07068109a594d

commit_message:
Add Davanum Srinivas' candidacy for Oslo

Change-Id: I232332354519da53d77ae56442e07068109a594d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/62/223362/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hi, It's been a great privilege to be the Oslo PTL for Liberty and getting to know and learn a whole lot of things. I hope i have helped move the Oslo project along its path in the process. Things we should be proud about include the fact that oslo-incubator is almost empty. We have a whole bunch of new libraries both general purpose outside of OpenStack and those who are specific to openstack. We as a team, have greatly stabilized core libraries like oslo.db and oslo.messaging etc as well. We have grown both the oslo core team and the cores for individual oslo projects to inject new blood into the project. Another aspect we really pushed hard is to make sure we did a lot of testing before we released code to reduce the chances of breaking projects as well as making sure that we stuck to a schedule of releases every week to release things early. For Mitaka, i would like to focus on Documentation. This has been a sore spot for a while and folks have to end up reading code quickly when things fail. I'd also like the team to finally get rid of the remnants in the oslo-incubator and spearhead adoption of the oslo libraries in various projects. Shadowing Doug in the previous cycle helped me along the way in liberty, so i'd love to show and help hand over the duties to the next ptl for the N release. Happy to do this even if there is a new PTL for the Mitaka release. As mentioned in the oslo meeting today, it would be great to have a VOTE and thanks for Joshua (and anyone else who may throw their hat) for making it a race :) Looking forward to new oslo libraries, more drivers for existing libraries and working together to make the OpenStack ecosystem more vibrant and welcoming to everyone. Thanks, Dims

added_lines: def _allocate_unique_key(self): key = '/tunnel_key/key' prev_value = 0 try: prev_value = int(self.client.read(key).value) self.client.test_and_set(key, str(prev_value + 1), str(prev_value)) return prev_value + 1 except Exception as e: if prev_value == 0: self.client.write(key, "1", prevExist=False) return 1 raise e def allocate_unique_key(self): while True: try: return self._allocate_unique_key() except Exception: pass

commit_message:
Adding Rossella Sblendido candidacy for Neutron

This is the official candidacy of Rossella Sblendido for the PTL
role for Neutron for the Mitaka release cycle.

Change-Id: Ie7ed7dba767c8f3aea7e65940736148ff79f50e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/57/223557/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hi everyone, I decided to run for the Neutron PTL position for the Mitaka release cycle. I have been contributing to Neutron since Havana and I am a member of the control plane core review team. During these years I have touched most parts of the Neutron code and in the last cycle my main focus has been to restructure the OVS agent, adding the ability to use events provided by ovsdb client and making it more resilient to failures. Mentoring people and spreading knowledge about Neutron have been high priorities for me in these years. I am a regular speaker at OpenStack events (local meetups, Openstack days and summits), where my talks have had high attendance and good feedback. I have been a mentor for the Outreachy program [1] and the OpenStack upstream training. If I become PTL these are my main objectives for Mitaka: * Make the community even more welcoming. Neutron is still facing a big challenge in terms of review bandwidth. Good features can't get merged because of this limit, even if the introduction of the Lieutenant system [2] has improved scalability, we still need to create a better way to share knowledge. In addition to improving the existing documentations and tutorials I'd like to create a team of mentors that can help new contributors (the quality of the proposed patches should increase so that the review time needed to merge them should decrease) and form new reviewers (more good people, more bandwidth). * Keep working hard to increase the stability. The introduction of functional tests and full stack tests was great, we just need to keep going in that direction. Moreover I'd love to produce and store some benchmark data so that we can also keep track of the performance of Neutron during time. * Continue getting feedback from operators. I think it's very important to hear the opinions of the actual Neutron users and to understand their concerns. * Paying down technical debt Introduce oslo versioned objects to improve RPC and keep refactoring Neutron code to make it more readable and understandable. Before proposing my candidacy I made sure I have the full support of my employer for this role. Neutron has a great team of contributors and great leaders, it would be an honor for me to be able to coordinate our efforts and push Neutron forward. Thanks for reading so far and for considering this candidacy, Rossella (rossella_s) [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Outreachy [2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/neutron/policies/core-reviewers.html#core-review-hierarchy

commit_message:
Fix event log errors in action modules

Currently, event log methods still need context as the first
parameter. Also it needs entity object rather than ID as the
second parameter. This patch fix related errors in cluster_action
and node_action modules.

Change-Id: I7e71afe1da63fa34968a9c8f4b6fd3736a8f0f8a

commit_message:
[RN 7.0] Auth issue with server for storing master backup

This patch adds the following resolved issue to the
Fuel Other resolved issues section of Release Notes 7.0:

- Authorization issue with server for storing master backup.

Change-Id: Ib962f48f1f1335ac2e00abdcfc9024ca98ecebf0
Related-Bug: #1352369
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/85/223585/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Other ----- Resolved issues +++++++++++++++ * Previously, if a user wanted to make a backup of an environment to a remote server, the authorization prompt appeared only after backing up all containers which could take about half an hour. And if a user did not enter the pass during the `LoginGraceTime` (the default value is 120 seconds), the connection was lost. Now the authorization prompt apperars first, and a key-based authentication is used to copy the backup archive. See `LP1352369`_. .. Links .. _`LP1352369`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/fuel/7.0.x/+bug/1352369

commit_message:
Update in-band agent raid spec

This commit updates the in-band agent raid spec to
add more details about the implementation.  It also
removes some of the agent ramdisk changes that were
specified, as it was not required.

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Tantsur <dtantsur@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I85220ffe9842576d73b91d194cfdaca6c437ebd2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/33/222133/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Ironic Python Agent (IPA). The drivers ``agent_ipmitool``, ``agent_ipminative``, ``agent_ssh``, ``agent_vbox`` and ``agent_ilo`` drivers will make use of this new implementation of ``RAIDInterface``.spec [1]. The implementation will be named ``AgentRAID``. The main* The following methods will be implemented as part of ``AgentRAID``: - Uses ``clean.execute_clean_step`` command in Ironic Python Agent ramdisk to invoke the ``create_configuration`` step of ``raid`` interface. - Uses ``clean.execute_clean_step`` command in Ironic Python Agent ramdisk to invoke the ``delete_configuration`` step of ``raid`` interface. + ``get_clean_steps`` - This will poll the agent ramdisk to get the clean steps belonging to the ``raid`` interface. It will change the priority of the raid clean steps returned by the agent ramdisk to 0 and then send it to the conductor. An empty list is returned if agent ramdisk returns an empty list for steps belonging to the ``raid`` interface. * Normally, when agent ramdisk is running an in-band clean step, Ironic conductor will poll the status of the last in-band clean step on every heartbeat. When an in-band clean step completes, Ironic conductor would just resume the cleaning. A new mechanism will be added for doing some operation after an in-band clean step is done. A new decorator ``agent_base_vendor.post_clean_step_hook`` will be added for driver implementors wishing to do something after an in-band clean step is done (in normal case, Ironic conductor will poll the status of the last in-band clean step and resume cleaning with the next clean step). Driver implementors can just decorate a method with this decorator and it will be invoked on the successful completion of the clean step. The decorated method would recieve ``task`` argument and the command status sent by agent ramdisk. For example:: @agent_base_vendor.post_clean_step_hook( interface='raid', step='create_configuration') def _create_configuration_final(task, command): * A method ``agent._create_configuration_final`` will be added as a post clean step hook for ``raid.create_configuration``. ``update_raid_info`` will be called in this method with the actual RAID configuration returned from the agent ramdisk. * A method ``agent._delete_configuration_final`` will be added as a post clean step hook for ``raid.delete_configuration``. This will set ``node.target_raid_configuration`` to ``None``.One alternative implementation possible is to decorate the methods ``AgentRAID.create_configuration`` and ``AgentRAID.delete_configuration``. This will cause the ``raid.create_configuration`` and ``raid.delete_configuration`` to be registered as a possible clean step irrespective of whether the bare metal hardware supports raid configuration or not. In such a case, execution of create_configuration will throw an error from the agent ramdisk saying no compatible hardware manager can be found. Also the ``GET /v1/nodes/NNNN/clean_steps`` will return ``raid.create_configuration`` and ``raid.delete_configuration`` as a possible clean step. This might be misleading to the operator and in-consistent with other in-band clean step implementation.* Implement the mechanism for post clean step hook. * Implement ``AgentRAID``use of ``AgentRAID`` will need to document it.[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/approved/ironic-generic-raid-interface.html
deleted_lines: Ironic Python Agent (IPA). The first driver to make use of this interface will be the ``agent_ilo`` driver.spec [1]. The implementation will be named ``AgentRAIDManagement``. The main* The following methods will be implemented as part of ``AgentRAIDManagement``: - Calls ``clean.create_raid_configuration`` on the agent ramdisk passing the details of ``raid_config``. - Calls ``clean.delete_raid_configuration`` on the agent ramdisk. * The results for both of the above commands will be polled on subsequent heartbeats from the ramdisk and then ``update_raid_info`` will be called once the RAID operation is done. * Agent ramdisk will be enhanced to add two new methods ``clean.create_raid_configuration`` and ``clean.delete_raid_configuration``. These methods will route the call to hardware manager, so that different hardware vendors can implement their own methods of managing RAID on their hardware. ``clean.create_raid_configuration`` will accept ``raid_config`` as argument (RAID configuration dictionary as mentioned in `New driver interface for RAID configuration`_. ``clean.delete_raid_configuration`` will not accept any arguments. .. _`New driver interface for RAID configuration`: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/liberty/ironic-generic-raid-interface.html * It is possible to have a hardware manager that does software RAID configuration. When software RAID configuration is done, agent based ``raid.create_config`` should be used as a clean step so that software RAID is configured everytime after a secure disk erase (which wipes out the previous software RAID configuration if it exists). Some bare metal servers do not support out-of-band RAID configuration. They support only in-band raid configuration. I don't see any other alternative other than making use of a ramdisk to do this.* Implement ``AgentRAIDManagement`` * Make changes in Ironic Python Agent to add methods ``clean.create_raid_configuration`` and ``clean.delete_raid_configuration`` which route calls to respective hardware manager. use of ``AgentRAIDManagement`` will need to document it. None.

Standardize Barbican error messages

Wrap Barbican's errors with a KeyManagerError instead of reraising the
Barbican exception.

commit_message:
Fix revert-resume Authentication Error

When we get private keys from the master node
there are two keys '/root/.ssh/id_rsa' and
 '/root/.ssh/bootstrap.rsa'.
An error occures when we try to use a wrong key,
but on the next iteration we use right one
and authentication passes.
So it's just cosmetic defect and patch fixes an exception
mechanism.

Change-Id: If167abc34f1c4060ab3b791204dc7245d06805d9
Closes-Bug: 1494856

Add information about reapplying puppet on deployed node

Change-Id: Ieb51e674ca151dbfc2ce00103ee08868899074a8
Closes-Bug: #1385615
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/30/223230/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Applying Puppet changes on a slave node ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ You may want to apply all changes on a slave node or just a single granular task so that Fuel Puppet changes take effect. To run a complete Puppet cycle on a slave node, run: * Update fuel-libraryX.X on Fuel Master ``yum update`` * Run ``fuel node --node NODE_ID --deploy`` If you want to just update puppet and apply a single task, then run: * Update fuel-libraryX.X on Fuel Master ``yum update`` * Run ``fuel node --node node-XX --deploy --task rsync_core_puppet hiera globals TASK`` .. note:: The tasks rsync_core_puppet, hiera, and globals are required for processing any Puppet changes.

commit_message:
Fix wrong file name in Basic environment

To install and configure the database server
3. Create and edit the /etc/mysql/conf.d/mysqld_openstack.cnf
===> file not found
needed to be changed to
3. Create and edit the /etc/mysql/my.cnf

Closes-bug: #1495287

commit_message:
Install Guide: Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

This change only updates the Install Guide.

Change-Id: I71ff1841af54f5db870e836bc1c62499096a712e

Add additional documentation around releasing sub-projects.

Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/56/222256/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * The released will now be on PyPi. Verify this by going to an URL similar to `this <http://https://pypi.python.org/pypi/networking-odl>`_. * Go to Launchpad and release this version using the "Release Now" button for the release itself. * Any bugs that were fixed with this release need to be updated to "Fixed Released" in Launchpad. * Add the tarball to the Launchpad page for the release using the "Add download file" link. * Add the next milestone to the Launchpad series, or if a new series is required, create the new series and a new milestone. * Send an email to the community announcing the new release.

commit_message:
Fix the heavy time cost of event-list

Acorrding the current event-list API, an admin user is allowed to query
all events which have traits.project_id value that match it's own project
OR any event without any project_id trait. In get_events() in
impl_sqlalchemy.py, this current query clause is implemented in a
inefficient way. This change make it more efficient.

Co-Authored-By: gordon chung<gord@live.ca>
Change-Id: I645a7def0552e2574da540e180b4f57d8770e96e
Closes-Bug: #1494440
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/91/222991/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: admin_owned_q = query.filter(sa.and_( models.TraitText.key == 'project_id', models.TraitText.value == event_filter.admin_proj, models.Event.id == models.TraitText.event_id)).limit(limit) non_proj_q = query.filter(~sa.exists().where( models.Event.id == admin_q.subquery().c.event_id)).limit( limit) _event_list = [] for q in [admin_owned_q, non_proj_q]: if event_filter_conditions: q = q.filter(sa.and_(*event_filter_conditions)) _event_list.extend(q.add_columns(models.Event.generated, models.Event.message_id, models.EventType.desc, models.Event.raw).all()) event_list = {} for e in sorted(_event_list,key=lambda e: e.generated)[:limit]: event_list[e.id] = api_models.Event(e.message_id, e.desc, e.generated, [], e.raw) else: if event_filter_conditions: query = query.filter(sa.and_(*event_filter_conditions)) query = query.order_by(models.Event.generated).limit(limit) event_list = {} # get a list of all events that match filters for (id_, generated, message_id, desc, raw) in query.add_columns( models.Event.generated, models.Event.message_id, models.EventType.desc, models.Event.raw).all(): event_list[id_] = api_models.Event(message_id, desc, generated, [], raw)
deleted_lines: query = query.filter(sa.or_(~sa.exists().where( models.Event.id == admin_q.subquery().c.event_id), sa.and_( models.TraitText.key == 'project_id', models.TraitText.value == event_filter.admin_proj, models.Event.id == models.TraitText.event_id))) if event_filter_conditions: query = query.filter(sa.and_(*event_filter_conditions)) query = query.order_by(models.Event.generated).limit(limit) event_list = {} # get a list of all events that match filters for (id_, generated, message_id, desc, raw) in query.add_columns( models.Event.generated, models.Event.message_id, models.EventType.desc, models.Event.raw).distinct().all(): event_list[id_] = api_models.Event(message_id, desc, generated, [], raw)

commit_message:
Raise minimum required python-ceilometerclient to 1.5.0

global-requirements is in a bit of a bad situation with
python-ceilometerclient on stable/juno and stable/kilo with version
caps.

On stable/juno, ceilometerclient is capped at <1.0.13 and on stable/kilo
the minimum required ceilometerclient is >=1.0.13.  This leaves no room
to release fixes for python-ceilometerclient on stable/juno.

And python-ceilometerclient 1.0.12 has an uncapped dependency on
oslo.utils which breaks stable/juno jobs.

So ideally what we'd need to do is sync ceilometerclient on stable/juno
with g-r stable/juno and release that as 1.0.15, blacklist 1.0.13 and
1.0.14 on g-r stable/juno.

Then to avoid overlap with g-r stable/kilo, we need to do a stable/kilo
release of python-ceilometerclient as 1.1.1 and make that the new
minimum required version in stable/kilo and cap g-r stable/kilo at <1.2.

And to avoid overlap with master g-r, we would raise the minimum
required version to >=1.2 (done here).  We use 1.5.0 per gordc since
1.5.0 is required for integration tests and full API support for master.

So basically we leave wiggle room for these branches:

1. stable/juno: 1.0.x
2. stable/kilo: 1.1.x
3. master (stable/liberty): 1.5.x and greater

Partial-Bug: #1494516

Change-Id: Ieb5949f9231d0f8c02fcb720fe1e60b51195ea81
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/86/222386/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python-ceilometerclient>=1.2.0

commit_message:
Return NOT_RUNNING when beam is not RUNNING

Change get_status to return NOT_RUNNING when
beam is not_running. Otherwise, pacemaker
will get stuck during rabbitmq failover and
will not attempt to restart the failed resource

Change-Id: I926a3eafa9968abdf07baa5f2d5c22480300fb30
Closes-bug: #1484280
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/48/223548/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return $OCF_NOT_RUNNING

commit_message:
Promoting visual machine performance(video, sound and other) in SPICE
Now, More and more enterprises use OpenStack as Desktop Virtualization Platform, it need improving remote display performance and playing music/sound files.
So, this blueprint hope improving display performance and supporting audio in Spice client.
Goals:
1. Add video device in libvirt config.
2. Add sound device in libvirt config.

This modifying remove needless whitespace!

Change-Id: I137becf7ce0a904f0f6c4fb5fbf4232f3b918ec6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/99/222699/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Promoting visual machine performance(video, sound and other) in SPICE

Now, More and more enterprises use OpenStack as Desktop Virtualization Platform, it need improving remote display performance and playing music/sound files.

So, this blueprint hope improving display performance and supporting audio in Spice client.

Goals:
1. Add video device in libvirt config.
2. Add sound device in libvirt config.

Blueprint libvirt-spice-video-sound-driver

Change-Id: Id988102184b4bae6f897eaf4f44e596fb2b89682

added_lines: Rolling back a node to its original state +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Starting with Fuel 7.0, you can use the rollback feature to return a node to its original state (e.g. the state before the node failed). This can be used to revert changes during a failed upgrade or other node malfunction. See :ref:`rollback-ug`.
